On draught at the Wellington, Bristol. pleasant bright gold colour with a decent white head. Aroma of sweet malt, a touch of honey and floral hops. Flavour was sweet with some dryness in the finish. Enjoyable.
Good clean beer. Heard budwieser got the name from them so I wanted to try it! It was very crisp with an aftertaste and flavor that was much better than bud!

An on par Bohemian pilsener. Nothing great. Aroma of skunk and a hint of hops. Pour was a light gold with a nice 2 finger white head. Taste was grainy and dry. A bit of light malt on the tongue with a little hop nod in the back. Typical for the style.
Bottle. Pours a light amber, golden colour with white head. Aroma of pilsner, sweetness, hop. Flavour is slight bitter and hoppy. Not a Pilsner man, so I didn’t really enjoy it.

This is a wonderful, smooth, very tasty beer that is well-deserving of its status as a classic.  It is a deep gold with a big, dense white head that slowly dissipates to a strong ring and wisps.  The aroma is strong of toasted bread, yeast, pine, with hints of honey and flowers.  The taste is strong with mostly sweet grain, biscuit with a light floral hop bitterness that becomes more pronounced just before the finish, which is an excellent marriage of banana and toasted grain.  The flavour is strong and persistent.  It’s incredibly smooth and pleasant, easy to drink but very full of flavour.
Overall, a pretty good pilsner. Light, bright with soft hops and decent malt.

A jewel -- oddly, gratifyingly old fashioned.  A very close relative to Urquell, just a bit more malty.  30-40 years ago, many German and Alsatian Pilsners tasted like this, hops were used more sparingly (not least because of expense).  A side effect of more malt was a more severe headache when overindulging which may have played a role in piling on the hops.  That coincided with the demand for ever-drier (especially white Riesling) wines by increasingly younger drinkers.

bouteille verte de 500ml.

bière de belle couleur dorée plus foncée que la moyenne, la mousse avait totalement disparue après 5 secondes. nez malté sur fond de houblon, la bouche est amère (bonne présence de houblon) elle est très longue en bouche, et surtout très agréable.
It’s a famous beer, and that’s right. Really good. A little bit spicy, not too dry. You shuold try it.

Pours a very light amber, almost transparent, with a diminishing medium white head.  The aroma is strongly skunky (a la Carlsberg) with a slight amount of citrus.  Taste has a slight amount of skunkiness in the palate, otherwise it is lightly ctirus.  It has some carbonation and is refreshing but nothing exciting.
Light amber, moderate head, hoppy aroma. The flavour has a slight sweetness and floral and hoppy notes. It’s refreshing.
Pours golden amber with modest head. Aromas of hops and barley with the flavour much the same. Well balanced and flavourful for a pilsener- definitely a winner.

This poured into a glass with a small pure white head that diminished rapidly. The aroma was of malt and hops but kinda faint. The flavor is really good. It’s like a typical earthy, skunky pils, but it has a little bite as well, which is kinda nice for this style. The taste is a little sweet also. The finish is slightly rough.

A fresh pils, a little thin-headed, though.
The aroma is of crisp malt and saaz and very clean.
The flavour is clean, too, with a nice crisp malt and saaz taste. Not much extravaganca, but a well brewed pils with a great summer-in-the-garden potential!

This beer is labeled "Czechvar Premium Lager"....12 oz bottle from 2006 beers of the world pack....golden color...smells like a cheap ass beer...looks like a cheap ass beer...and the conclusion is....foul...foul...foul...and oh this beer is foul...this beer was given to the sink to drink....

For some reason the label (in the USA) calls this a Czech lager, not a pilsener.  No head, gold color.  This is a nice, hoppy brew - those unique Saaz hops make it similar to Pilsner Urquell.  Maybe there is a historical connection to Budweiser, but this is not noticable in the flavor.  There is a hint of citrus in the aroma and it tingles on the tongue.  The aftertaste is pleasantly hoppy.  This whets the appetite for more fine examples of Czech brewing.
Pours golden and effervescent with a fully receeding off-white head. Aroma of herbal hops, cookie, and light hop resins. Mouthfeel is light to medium bodied with lively carbonation. Very nice.
this beer is more then the legend, with a great history the clean crisp taste still holds strong as one of the greats

Pours a clear yellow gold with a frothy white head that dissapates.  Aroma of bread, hay.  Very light sweet taste with some bitterness.  Light body,  but not thin.  The finish quenches the thirst after working at home in the yard.

11.2 oz bottle. Pours bright golden with thin white head. Nose is lightly spicy, grassy hops, doughy malt aroma. This beer has a round malty middle, very pure graininess, with a touch of slighly floral hop oils. Finish has a bit of bitterness, that fades quickly. An excellent example  of a bohemian pilsner.
12 oz bottle. Looked good after the pour with a strong, long-lasting head. But lost carbonation quickly and was difficult to finish after that. Left a bit of gritty film on my teeth.
color dorato carico con riflessi rossastri aroma di luppolo non molto fine in bocca abbastanza equilibrata tra malto e luppolo corpo esile
.5L Bottle Marburg, Germany- nice crisp pilsner aroma and taste.  Great to try the REAL thing; much more grainy tastey and full bodied than the AB type.

having tried to brew a plain jane back-to-basics pilsener recently, i am somewhat humbled by comparing mine to budvar, one of the benchmark "ur" brews of the style. several distinct aspects of this beer impress me-- ones that are deceptively simple, yet as evasive as wildlife to those that try to approach clumsily: they are the perfect diamond-clarity of the pour, and the fragile aroma of hops. these qualities i’ve learned are easy to drown out and besmudge in the crowded porridge of extract wort and the bumbling of novice brewing.  budvar’s color is as arresting as the iridescent banana yellow of a traffic light, and the head is as purely white as aphrodite’s underwear--tho all but a doily of foam implodes and disappears within seconds. the hops, however lush, are not exactly the citrusy or piney aroma i would have expected: rather a bit of peanut shell, a note of rubber band and freshly laundered cotton. perhaps one can evoke the smell of a number two pencil, the kind with the thick yellow paint and tooth marks on it. it remains very pleasant, and the taste is a cool washing away of even that gooey, reclusive thirst that can hide behind the back molars. lots of briskly carbonated water carries white grape vinous flavors in a chilling torrent through the mouth, while a gesture of honey animates the bread stick malts as gently as a butterfly steps on flower stamens. this sample came to me NOT on a cargo ship packed in palettes and kilo tons-- but in a suitcase carefully husbanded by my own girlfriend across the pond, so you can be sure i savored every sip. you betcha: this bud was for me.
So good to try this beautiful pilsner again. Sweet aftertaste nad hoppy aroma, jsut as it should be.

16.9 oz bottle.  Have to say I was a bit disappointed with this.  I’m sure it would have been much better on draft.  Smell was a bit off, taste was just a bit musty / funky.  Rich golden color, smooth & full mouthfeel, but stale taste.  I’ll have to do this one again.

16.9 oz bottle. Pours a rather nice looking crysta clear golden orange with large sized soda bubbles carbonation with an average size slick white head. Aroma of malts, cereal grain, fruit and slight syrup. Medium palate with very lively carbonation and a quickly disipating aftertaste. Flavor is very light compared to the aroma with pilsner malt and slight fruitiness. A drinkable lager.

Bottle Eulogy Tavern in Olde City Philadelphia-Pours a typical golden yellow coloring with a grassy and hops aroma and flavors.  Pretty well balanced with no after taste.  Pretty enjoyable overall. We drank 2. I’d equate it to a nice Sam Adams Light

Draft @ U Medvidku.  My first real taste of Czech pilsner.  Served in a huge .5L stein, with at least an inch of head on top, not too much overwhelming in any stage of the beer, grassy hop aroma, doughy bready taste and rather full for a lager, mild tingly medicinal hop bitterness in the finish cleansing the palate and asking for more.  Just a truly solid beer, oh so quaffable and enjoyable.
Bottle. Grassy pils nose with a light hop aroma. Smooth but not much depth. Slightly bitter with a sour finish. Enjoyable with a smooth palate. Pale yellow, thin white head.

I’m becoming really fond of this beer. I’ve had is in Europe (the Budvar label) and now in the States (Czechvar). The scent this beer produces as soon as you pop the cap is great; a floral hoppy aroma.  Golden color with a quickly diminishing white head. I like the aftertaste; wouldn;t call it sweet but its not bitter at alll. Makes you want to drink another one. And another one.

Green bottle Czechvar (Budwiser not mentioned on bottle anywhere). Bottle i got was skunked and smelled bad. Fortunately it tasted better than it smelled, but i wouldnt rate it any better than a Coors. My bottle purchased 2 days ago said best before 8/2006.
Small average head,smooth golden color. Soft cracker aroma-more wheatthin than saltine. Subtle hop, pretty simple but well balanced.
Well-balanced and refreshing pilsener. Good mineral taste to it creates some unusual depth for a light beer. Relatively lightly hopped without being sweet. A fine choice

Draft at Bull and Castle, Dublin. Pour was pale golden color, slight true yellow-ness to it, but not much. Head was pretty generous initially but subsided. The aroma was grainy, bready, slight grassiness. The flavor followed suit, somewhat of a pale lager, yet retaining some aspects of true pilsner character. Light in the flavor, light in the mouthfeel, better than US Bud (no obvious adjunct presence to me), but certainly not a top notch Pilsner.
Draft in Prague poured out in a Budvar glass mug.  Clear golden colour with a medium white head, good lacing.  Better than macros, similar to Urquell.
Very good pilsener, less bitter than Urquel. Very refreshing, good aftertaste.

Rerate in Prague: Fresh and malty, with very nice hops in aroma and flavor.   (original) 33cl bottle from Systembolaget.   Clear gold with a small, unstable head.   Aroma was an initial rush of grassy, tangy, earthy hops, and then sweet caramel and bread.   Malt dominates, with just enough hops to keep it from being overly sweet, but the hop flavor doesnt seem assertive to me.  Slight betterness actually leaves a long but subtle finish, which is suprising.  It’s well balanced and delicate, with a light body and smooth carbonation.   Being an American, I had to try this in Europe and see if it was better than Budweiser, and it certainly is, but it’s nothing special for a Czech pilsner.   Urquell still wins in my book.

Bottle, label is Czechvar comes with green bottle topped with nice gold foil. Pours a clear golden with thin white head. Aroma came out faintly oxidized, but very grassy and slightly herby. Body is light and fizzy. Flavor is lightly bitter, with some bready malts, lots of grassy hops. Finish is dry, lightly bitter, fairly clean and short. Not bad at all.
12 ounce bottle purchased at Winn Dixie Broward County, FL under Czechvar name $1.50

12oz bottle. funny to say i got this from an AB wholesaler. ha! nice golden color is clear and clean. white frothy head forms about one finger tall and thins out fast. nose was present from the moment the bottle opened. mostly saaz hops, but plenty of grass and herbs. crisp and smooth but a little thin overall. very drinkable, and quite refreshing. i think i’ll stick with urquell when i want my pilsner fix.

Bottle. Got this as an extra in trade.  Aroma is all toasty malts with maybe a hint at floral hops.  Pours a clear golden yellow white foamy head.  Flavor is all bready toasty malts though sweet.  Palate is ok finishes relatively clean. Overall, not too bad.

Bottle: Std. Pint Glass.
A pale yellow gold colour, far better than the American Budweiser commercial lot. Pours with a great white pristine head with loads of carbonation. Good lacing too. A breaded malty taste, strong hoppy, with not much else in it. A bit light and watery to tase.

12oz bottle.  Pours a pale straw color with good carbonation and a fleeting head.  Aroma is sweet and earthy with floral notes alongside honey, corn, yeast, and malt.  Body is creamy and fairly full for the style with a creamy opening giving way to a longer finish of sweet and earthy flavors.  One of the better lagers or pilsners I can recall.
This is part of a beer club. Had only one bottle but was decent for the price. Poured great and had a nice finish. Would do again.

From the bottle.  This pours with a medium head, nice lacing, and beautiful dark golden hue.  Smell of floral hops, with a light bready malt balance.  Distinct taste, very bitter, great balance and nice bread and yeast flavors. The texture is slightly watery, but ends with some nice, dry crispness and a medium lived grapefruity finish.  A wonderful pilsner.

Bottle sampled. Pours golden with a white fizzy head. Aroma of grassy hops, pale malts, citrus, and corn adjuncts. The flavor is slight grain sweetness upfront, citrusy mild bitter hops in the finish, with mild corn and dryness.

Wow!  I was impressed by this one!  Great flavor, good hoppiness without it being overpowering, and nice light texture.

Now THIS is what a lighter pilsener should be like!

Couleur or-pâle clair, mince mousse qui persiste. Arôme plutôt faible de gazon, équilibre malt-houblon. Goût sucré de malt plutôt prenant au début avec effervescence moyenne à forte et s’estompant rapidement à la fin, laissant l’arôme des houblons. Le corps semble moyen et fait place à un côté mince à la fin.Très désaltérant et avec le déséquilibre en bouche c’est  surprenant.
Flaske. Aftenens vinder. Skarp frisk humlesmag der rammer perfekt. Yderst frisk og drikbar øl, med en flot farve.
The American Budweiser is put to absolute shame by the Czech Budweiser. Very good beer.
pours pale gold with a fluffy short lived head. lager aroma, corn, wet burlap and a little malt. flavor is the same with a little floral hoppiness and a slight hay bittered finish.

0.5 l bottle. Pours pale yellow body with moderate white head. Great aroma of flowers, citrus, corn and other hops and some malt too. Taste well balanced to be neutral. I would prefer a bit bitter pilsener, but fine. Nice palate, maybe leaving too light and watery impression. Good but not the best.
Grassy, smooth, delicious. What BUD should taste like, but you know that already. A great solid pilsner.

12 oz bottle.  Golden yellow with vegital aromas.  Slightly skunky.  Flavor was much better.  Nice sweet malty start with a real hop character.  Nice finish.  Very refreshing.  Would love to try this fresh in it’s home country.
A really good pilsner lager.  light, but not "watered down" like most american macros.  Slightly sweet, slightly malty, slightly hopped, slightly dry....

Poured a clear golden color with white head that dissipated rather quickly.  Malty aroma that is not very dominant.  Taste is malty also, with a bit of sweetness to it.  This is not my preferred style and I did not find it that enticing.  If I never had another I wouldnt feel like I was missing anything.  Smooth, good mouthfeel.

Assaggiata dal bicchiere altrui al Pub del Duca, buona pils ceca che teme pochi rivali soprattutto oggi che la Urquell perde colpi. Nonostante non sia il mio genere, penso che ci ritornerò. Stay tuned.______________ENGLISH TEXT HERE______________Sampled from Dude’s glass at the Duca’s Pub, nice czech pils, better than Urquell imho.

Name: Czechvar Original Premium Czech Lager

Date: August 09, 2001

Mode: Bottle

Source: Wild Wing Cafe, Marietta

Appearance: yellow, headless

Aroma: light malt aroma

Flavor: good malt flavor with crisp hop flavor



Name: Czechvar Original Premium Czech Lager

Date: April 21, 2007

Mode: bottle

Source: tasting

Score: 2.7 to 2.6

Appearance: clear pale yellow, wispy white head

Aroma: light corn aroma with faint floral hops

Body: creamy body

Flavor: lightly sweet malt flavor, touch of corn, nice balancing floral hops



Name: Czechvar Original Premium Czech Lager

Date: August 03, 2008

Mode: draft

Source: summits woodstock

Appearance: clear gold, fine dirty white head, thick patterned lace

Aroma: sweet cereal malt aroma with nice spicy hops

Flavor: clean malt flavor, touch of sweet cereal, nice spicy floral hops, light bitterness



Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 10/20

Rating: 2.6/5.0
Drinkability: 7/10

Score: ** /4

This is what a light lager should taste like. Crisp and refreshing. It’s the gateway beer in my opinion, or at least it was for me. Once people have this, they should stop drinking all the american macro shit.
Give me a Sausage on Toast and a big bottle of Bud for 65k --- never go to McDonald’s again.
Another winner from the Czechs. A lot better than Pilsener Urquell. Overly dry tasting at times I find though.
Tried both in bottle and on tap in the CR. Decent beer with peppery overtones. Not as full-bodied as I expected or would have preferred. Very dry. It will pair well with food.

Bottle. Light gold with ample head.  Medium carbonation.  Grassy aroma. Refreshing medium bodied.  Well balanced.  Not bitter - leans to the sweet side a bit.
Easy to drink.
Clear and light in colour. Budvar is a very easy drinker. Nice fluffy head with a slight malty taste and a grassy aftertaste.

Crisp clear golden color. Slight head, some lacing. Smells like a pilsner- graqssy, even slightly pungent, sulfury. Taste matches- clean,tones of grass, it’s got that pilsner "skunk" (not to be meant as a negative)- but it’s not overpowering. I prefer this in a pilsner. Not as dry as others, but dry enough. Carbonation is nice. Some bitterness. Nice to sit back and put a few away in the summer."
draft.  light golden pour.  minimal head with white tones.  medium body with nice hop texture.

I had this beer in Prague during an evening of bar hopping and was more than impressed. Pours well, good body, and no bitterness. It tastes even better when its a $1 per pint. I also had it in a bottle and only noticed a slight dropoff in taste.

From tap. Pours golden yellow, slight hazy and with a white head. Aroma is classic pilsener malt with a corn note. Flavour is soft malty, slight sweet with a good bitterness into the finish. Good brew.

Draft (tank) - Hazy golden body, fine white head, fine lacing; Pleasant fresh simple malty nose; Big soft carbonation on soft body, malty bitter; Medium long malty buttery slightly bitter balanced but not really complex finish. Very drinkable but to simple.

12 oz. bottle (Czechvar).  Pour is golden yellow (a bit deeper than a Pale Lager) with a nice white head.  Aroma was a touch of skunk initially, which gave way quickly to some nice earthy hoppiness.  Spicy, earthy hops are the main component of the taste with a bit of sweet sugar malt in there as well.  Finish is crisp and clean.  Nice beer.

Clear yellow with a medium sized, lasting head. Grain aroma, with fruit, hay and herbs. Initially rather sweet for a bohemian pilsner, but with with a good, lasting hoppiness that beats most of the competition in the world.


Tank pub in Prague 2008: Malty and sweet ith just the right amount of hops. Pretty much the same rating.

[452-20070727] Sample @ LCBO-Summerhill. Faint smoky grains and fruit aroma. Clear, orange yellow body with a quick foamy white head. Mainly grainy leaves with a nice sweet aftertaste. Medium body has some astringency. Interesting texture.
green bottle under czechvar name.  tiny bit of skunk, but nothing overwhelming, a clean malty taste, mild bitterness, pleasantly surprised
i was looking for the dark version of this, it was a great beer. this ones good as well.

500 ml bottle from the LCBO. poured golden yellow with a very small white head that quickly dissapeared. aromas: a little skunk from the green bottle, floral hops, small amount of bread malt. flavours are in perfect balance with a nice bitter finish. a good example of an everyday beer. if this came in non-green bottle id buy it more often but everytime i pick up a green bottle i know im taking a gamble. this is a great brew and i will try to enjoy it more often//////////////////////////////////weve only been getting cans of this one into the LCBO lately and it doesnt even taste like the same beer, no hops, minimal malt, chunky protein floaties. pretty much destroyed. i dont buy this beer anymore.

Less bitter than most 12’ czech beers, but enough to give balance to the fruity hop flavour that makes this just a little bit better than it’s rivals. Foam is almost legendary in it’s ability to disappear instantly, but without seriously damaging the crisp taste of a unique beer.

Crisp, clean, hoppy, with a smooth finish.  If only American Budweiser was this good!  Anheuser Busch could take a tip or two from Budvar.  This is, to me, what a prototypical basic beer should be like.  The fact that pale lager has completely dominated as the style of choice for Beer in North America is disheartening.
Good Not great. Aroma is better than the flavor.   Drink it if it is there but don’t go out of your way to get it.

Green bottle from LCBO. Another one I never realized I havent rated. From memory. A golden pils with a thick white head. Aroma of grains, and unfortunate skunk (why green, guys). In mouth, a fresh grainy malt with green hops, mineral notes, a bit salty. Medium bodied. Not as good as I remembered.
If on tap in Prague the score would be a 3.0-3.3 score if in a brown bottle the taste would probably be 2.9-3.1.

Bottle. Clear golden colour with medium creamy white mostly diminishing head.  Very hoppy aroma. Sweet fruity flavor.
very good pilsner.

Ostenta coloração dourada translúcida, com ótima formação e duração do creme. No aroma e no sabor, agradável floral de lúpulo e ótimo balanceamento entre este e o malte, também claramente perceptível. A carbonatação é média e o final é levemente amargo e lupulado, com uma drinkability excelente.

Bottle. $2. Pours gold with a small white head. Aroma has some nice wild hop touches, as well as a little dry fruit. Flavor is a bit grainy, with some fruitiness, and spices there to lead the way to a peppery hop dry finish.

331 ml green bottle - Clear gold with a thin white head which soon died away. Medium body and carbonation. Smooth, malty, with slightly spicy, flowery hop flavours and a soft bitterness in the finish. Pleasant and refreshing!

Bottle-Poured a clear golden color w/a slight white head. Slight hop aroma. Floral hop flavor w/traces of spice & citrus. Had a lot of carbonation to it. Not a bad brew, but nothing special-kind of tasted like watered down Stella. As someone who grew up drinking Bud I always wanted to try this beer, scored some @ a 4th of july cookout: don’t even know who brought it, but thanks!
Yellow/orange. Standard pilsner aroma. Works well enough but a little overcarbonated.
bottle-1pint9ounces. gold with a nice white head that disappeared quickly. This one went down smoothly and I tasted a pleasant but not overpowering hint of hops.

1pt., 9 floz bottle. Pours a rich golden color with a foamy white head that quickly dissapates; no lacing observed. Aroma of hops and corn. Taste is light  with grains, malts and yeast. Mouthfeel is full without being heavy. Finish is clean and slightly hoppy. A classic pils-lager. This would make a good lawnmower beer.

I tried this beer on June 26, 2007 after purchasing from my local LCBO store.  It poured a beautiful golden translucent colour.  The aroma was a nice grainy aroma that screamed ’drink me!’  It is smooth and crisp on the tongue with small hints of carbonation.  The favour is crisp and clean with hints of grain.  I will definitely try this again.

best pilsner i ever had. really intense flavor (for a pilsner even greater for a lager). tangy and bitter but without a tingly bite. nice malt tang in the back of the tongue. interesting aroma is quite fruity under the circumstances. and $1.99 for a 25 oz! light lemon grassy? interesting woodish burp (i highly doubt that it is beechwood...ooorrrr  iiss it? nice.

Lovely gold appearance, minimal head. Lacing sticks around the edges. Aroma is hard to detec. Taste is malts, then yeast, and some bitter hops at the end. Carbonation is light and works perfectly. This is a very well-balanced beer, and well-made. No complaints!

Bottle: Pours bright gold in color with a strong white head. SMell is a bit lemony. Taste is crisp, with a bit of a buttery feel, but also soft. There is just a hint of hop in the aftertaste. As I continue to drink, the taste gets more and more bitter, very interesting. Tastes a bit dry as well.
strong aroma and lots of carbonation and hoppiness, a world away from the american version, but not quite the top lager that people make it out to be
Hoppy, bittersweet, dances on the tongue, clean, soft malt. One of my favourite lagers, I was sure I’d already rated it...

Bottle purchased in Cork, IRE.  Didn’t have a best by date or anything but the aroma seems very fresh, crisp, and with the pale malts shining through.  Gold body with a nice white head.  Taste is clean, faint hop content, probably the ultimate lawn mower beer.

It was cisp and clean until the dirty aftertaste.  A refreshing beer that would be much better if it finished cleaner.  I am a little confused about the Budweiser connection.  Guess I’ll read up, but with another brand.
16.9 oz bottle North America. Pour clear golden color with white head. Aroma of lite hops and malt. Taste of malt and hops with very clean finish with no after taste good pilsener.
On tap.  Pours out a clear amber color.  smell of hops, malt, corn, bread and minor flowers.  Taste of light malt, touch of sugar, corn, grains and hops.
Great beer. Loved the fact that while tending bar in the UK most patrons were ignorant enough to think this is an american beer. The second  best Bohemian Pilsner behind urquell.

One of my favourites pilsners, luckily this has become widely available in Ireland in the last year or two. Unluckily barmen often serve it without a glass or (wose) in a glass with ice. The beer has a nice malty bite would a strong hoppy finish. Lovely.
Garrafa, julho/2008. Coloração dourada um pouco mais escura, com boa formação de creme. Presença bem dosada de malte e lúpulo, com leve floral. Carbonatação média agradável. Boa drinkability.

Another one from shigadeyo. Pours a light clear yellow witha small white head. Inital aroma mild skunk but that quickly fades and then corn, light malts, and citrus appear. Flavor is bitter corn, grains and citrus. Gets a little maltier as it warms. Finish is sort of dry. Not bad.
Beer 82 Summer 2006 trip in Europe.  Drank on 7/16/06 @ a Street Stand in Wezenclas Square.  Light airy beats the hell out of American shitty Bud.

Pours with a decent head but low quality for a pils....faint smell of hops and light skunkers....nice and bitter....lacing is not good for a pils either....nate liked it....A good beer but was expecting something MUCH better ,even for a pils lover like me!

Had in US bottle (Czechvar), purchased at Bottleworks, Seattle.  Aroma is sweet malt forward, with some corny notes and light hop flavor aroma.  Appearance is clear golden yellow, with an even white head, very bubbly.  Flavor is very crisp, with some sweet malt, and what seemed to be some slightly oxidized notes, lightly bitter, sour, with low aftertaste.  Mouthfeel has a strong carbonation bite, slightly grainy, with a dry clean aftertaste.  Overall, the beer was slightly disappointing from what I’d heard, but I might have been drinking an older bottle; may re-rate when I’m by someplace that has it on draught.

This hit me like a brick when I was in Czeske Budejovice with the late Prof. Helgeson- like a wonderful Euphoric brick!
I have yet to taste a better beer - although be careful, it doesn’t age well, it is worth a trip to CZ just to taste the original.

Bottle, 33 cl. Deep clear golden, medium fluffy white head. Bready malts, some butterscotch notes, and vague hints of floral hops. Medium bodied and smooth. Starts off pleasantly sweet, and a moderate yet firm bitterness balances this beer very well.

(Bottle 50) Incredibly beautiful full golden colour with a rather large head. Fresh nose of barley. Lots of sweet malt and less bitternes thanother chzech lagers. Velvety soft body. 
Really good pilsner lager

Rated 6/1/07:  Impressive pour, nice light gold color with a big frothy white head and layers of lacing. The carbonation is absolutely insane, I’ve never seen anything like it. Airy malt aroma light and faint, low hop presence. Filling mouthfeel, real creamy and still delicate. Taste came across as rather standard, nicely balanced very mild just like the aroma. Not too much character involved here but it’s a good easy drink. Of course my bottle states best before 10/2006 so perhaps the flavor and aroma has mellowed a bit, but I still find this to be a good lager.
Nice lager. Malty and a little more hoppy than your standard run of the mill stuff. I’d like to visit there someday.
Bottle in at Grand Hyatt Berlin. Golden colour. Foamy head. Skunky nose. Hoppy taste. Prickly. Smooth finish. Enjoyable. Surprised I hadn’t tasted this one yet.

Golden colour with a white head which dissapears extremely quickly. The aroma is light, sweet notes of malts and bready notes of hops. Good flavour, with malts of front, some bready middle and a light note of bitter hops at the end. Light body and good balance make the drinkability of this beer pretty damn good.

Bottle. Pours a golden color with a very small white head. Mild aroma of hops. Very crisp, fresh flavor or hops and mild malt. The  palate is pretty thin which makes it a good beer to drink on a warm day, very refreshing.
Bottle. Clear golden colour with a white head. A nice, mostly hoppy aroma with notes of over ripe banana. Light malty flavour, a bit watery. Soft hoppy finish.
A nice pilsner.  Very good to drink on a hot summer day.  Better than the pilsner Urquell.
A classic brew, looks beautiful with its white head. Well-balanced, hoppy and malty, very full flavour.

Let’s go to Czechland. Green bottle labeled Czechvar Premium Czech Lager product of the Czech republic.  Now, since I am tasting this, I can’t wait to try Bud Super Strong by this same brewer!  Contrary to the picture here, this is a green bottle. Pop the lid, and you get a prettystrong cooked vegetable aroma that is from the cabbage variety, intense for a split second.  Ubiquitous pale yelolow american beer color and shade. Good medium carbonation greets the tongue even tho there is not any bubbles in the brew. In the glass the aroma is more yeastlike. Mild odd machine metallic (hop?) bitterness builds that leads to a short tight finish. Much more personality compaared to "american buweiser"

Bottle.Golden color with a nice white head that fade out slowly. Aroma of hops and malt. Palate of malt, little bit sweet. and with a good bitterness.One of the best pilsens.
Cerveja Dourada com uma espuma densa que vai sumindo aos poucos. Aroma de malt e lúpulo, um pouco doce a amarga na medida. Uma das melhores.
Bottle 0,33ltr: Saw this one at the local liquor store, and why not lets buy it. An golden coloured Bohemian Pilsener thats a little bit sweet and a good bitter finish.
From an old Cellar’s tasting note sheet.  More hop taste than I’m used to from a pilsner.  Lagery hint to the nose.

35 cl. bouteille. Aroma of spicy/floral hop. Kind of spicy anyway. Orange tinged golden color with a white head that quickly departed. Full bodied. Starts with some biscuity malt, but mostly hop. It’s more maltily flavorful than Urquell, but it’s not quite so crisp. This is good with spicy food. A worthy finish to the evening.

Bouteille. De couleur dorée et transparente. Nez de houblon floral, de grains de malt pâle avec des notes de maïs sucré ainsi que des notes herbeuses (foin). Plutôt mince en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et croustillant et une texture aux notes crémeuses. Goût de grains de malt pâle croustillant lors de l’entrée en bouche suivi d’un léger goût de biscuits accompagné d’un goût herbeux (foin) parallèlement à un goût moyennement amer de houblon floral et herbeux (notes d’herbes mouillées) jusqu’en finale. Post-goût moyen et un peu sec, moyennement amer de houblon floral et herbeux (foin et herbe mouillée).

Finally get to try a somewhat fresh bottle of this.  12oz, Best before 11/2007.  Pours a crstyal clear pale yellow with a one finger bone white head, fading to a thick ring after a minute or two.  Aroma of spicy, grassy hops, a fafir amount of biscuits and grain.  Immediately upon opening there was a bti of skunk, but this seems to have passed.  Flavor doesn’t seem to be terribly high hopped, and the sweet malts and grain become more apparent, as the spicy grassiness fade out more than I would’ve liked. There is some light wet paper in there as well, and a minimal bitterness.  Low carbonation with a light to medium body.  I was slightly disappointed with this, though I would favor it over the US Budweiser any day.  A refreshing summer brew.

This is not how I remember this beer. The one I’m having now must be slightly skunked, and the flavor is not as crisp as I was expecting. It’s also a bit watery and limp. Normally, this is a great berr, but not this time. Hmmm. It’s still heaps better than Bud/Miller/Coors. [12 oz. bottle, BevMo]
nice regular pilsner, crisp easy drinking a little czeck hops nothing crazy but a good easy drinker for the summer
Golden color with a nice white head. Aromas of hops and malt. Palate of malt, little bit sweet. and with a good bitterness. One of the best pilsens that I tried.
Prauge-07. Nothing special, a standard pilsner with golden colour, high carbonation, and crisp hops.

Must be about a 500ml bottle (no volume on bottle.) Name on label Czechvar, Premium Czech Lager. Poured golden with a quickly dissipating head. Lightly hopped aroma. There were notes of floral hops and light malt with a touch of sweetness. I’m not really getting much of anything here. Very pale, very weak taste. Not much better than an American Pale lager.

big bottle:  Very disappointing, after the initial aroma raised my hopes.  Very yeasty, and very, very sour.  Thin little white head dissolved within seconds, which should have been my cue.  Give me a Steamwhistle, Mill Street Organic, JR Brickman, or Walkerville Premium Blonde (good local craft brews), or even a  Kozel or anytime - far, far superior brews!  I think I need to eat something to get this sour aftertaste out of my mouth, yuck.  The corn reminds me of Faxe.  How can malt & hops cancel each other out so completely?This beer has a thin body & no finish to speak of.
Pours a light yellow color with a white head.  Aroma is lightly malty, some corn, with some hops.  Flavor is light malt and some spicy hops.
Poured a clear effervesent pale yellow wiht a small white head.  The aroma was a mix of malt and skunk.  Malty lightly sweet and grainy malt.

I’m really starting to like the Pilseners and was looking forward to this one.  It was definately good.  Nice hoppy aroma and flavor.  I love Urquell and I was hoping to enjoy this one just as much.  I would put this one a notch below Urquell, but it’s pretty close for me.  Now I gotta figure out how I’m gonna get to the Czech Republic to try all the pilseners from the source.
Bottle: a little fruity, a little floral, some hops, some mild bitterness, the overall flavor is pretty weak, very drinkable, makes a good thirst-quencher, but not more then that.

OH MAN. Ok, large pale frothy head, aroma is a perfect blend of Pils malts and classic Saaz hops, sometimes with a touch of skunk from the green bottle, but it actually almost works its way into the character of the beer, and is not  a problem. Not as Urquell, but still has a great kick to it, actually kind of sweet, and oh so smooth! Almost like a Helles. Great finish and aftertaste. I am in love. I don’t know which one’s better, Urquell or Budvar, whatever, I can drink both forever and be completely satisfied! An absolute must have for anyone who love’s pilsners in my humble opinion. RE-RATE: I still love this beer, and it’s still one of my favourites after all this time. It has such a perfect oily mouth-feel and bready malt flavour mixed with Saaz hops. I can’t resist it, even in the slightly skunky green bottle we get here in North America. I could drink only this for the rest of my life.....

12 oz. bottle- color of pale yellow , with a thick but thin white head – crisp nose of  straw , hay , hint of metal , and  mild hops – taste of straw , hay , corn , hint of metal , and  mild hops - body is dry , light , and with low carbonation – aftertaste of  bitter skunkyness , mild citrus zest , and mild hops

in bottle from Eulogy Belgian Tavern in Philadelphia. why my brother ordered a bottled beer when there were so many good beers on tap I don’t know, but he’s not a beer person so I guess I’ll excuse it. he lived in prague for awhile and says this was a favorite beer of his and many when he was there. sort of run of the mill beer but a bit amplified. pilsner. sort of smells like eggs. wheat. light hops. tastes peppery, eggey, light hops, grass, wheat. s’okay. I don’t think i’d order it again. too peppery for my taste and not complex enough. but its a drinkable beer.
Bottle.Clear light amber color.Mild hops aroma.Slight sweetness followed by slight bitterness.No flavors really stand out.Smooth,easy to drink.Pretty good.
This one pours a beautiful clear color with a nice head.  The first  impression is a strong skunkiness.  It has a small bit of malty sweetness combined with a brush of bitterness at the end.
0.5 L bottle. nice deep golden colour with amber tint, malty aromas,  extremly smooth, nice medium finish, excelent session beer.

Rumor in the back alleys and doorway is AB is buying this brewery. *sigh* Will it become the beer in the iron mask? Anyway, thils is good, but not GREAT pils. Poured with a light while head and some lace. Hoppy bitter beer. Crisp. Clean. Very drinkable. Definitely a session. Think I pick up a little corn in there tho. Nice bittersweet finish. Had a bottle of this from the colder glass front cooler at the Bodega Brew Pub downtown La Crosse, Wisconsin.

A golden Pilsener. Very nice aroma. Sweet notes that remind somewhat of pineapple. Slightly musty, but in a positive sense. Excellent taste, very biscuity, smooth beer. Very drinkable. Can’t say anything bad about this beer. A wonderful Pilsener. Rerate: Staying with the initial rating. Very accessible and pleasant.

Pours, clear and golden, aroma of hops and yeast.  Flavor is of a crisp, light bodiness with a floral hoppiness.  Sheeesh,  these Czech’s always boast about their beers, all I can say is that it was fairly good, but not a homer.  Don’t get me wrong I CAN drink lots of this beer, but sheeesh, its not that damn great.  Overall a good sessionable beer.

Bright yellow-gold with a quick white head. Bready malt aromas with some strong piney hop overtones. Follows through with crisp dry pale malts and a zesty, floral hop finish. Very drinkable, spicy, and full flavored.

Budweiser Czechvar
12 oz bottle
Best before 10/07, absorbed 03/07.
Medium pour in a pilsner flute.

Poured clear golden with a small white fizzy quickly diminishing head .

Smelt of moderate bread and perfume hops.

Taste was upfront moderate sweet bread and perfume hops followed by a moderate bitter rustic yeastiness with more light sweet bread and perfume hops on a long finish.

Palate was light bodied, fizzy, and slightly oily.

Overall, a seemingly disappointing beer that actually has a mighty fine taste.
world class pils. great aroma, and the flavour is nice and malty with a crispness i love. great stuff.

Bottle, poured a pale yellow bright and clear gold with a creamy white head, fragrances of sweet malt and faint cereal-bread, fresh hop fragrance that has a little spice, a pilsner malt fragrance, malt taste with a small hop bite, very smooth and dry on the palate, some creaminess in the mouth, a nice drink.

bottle- sampled in beers of the world class. small head disperses quickly.  pale golden color. smokey skunky aroma really skunky. i may have to rerate because the smell and taste was just sooo skunked. grassy taste, with a bitter hoppy finish. some floral taste maybe from the hops its hard to really get the taste since it is so skunked.

Tap, Port Mahon, Oxford. Attractive pale gold, persistant fine white head. Soft grassy hop aroma, mild but pleasant. Softly bready malt, soft and rather restrained herbal hops, just soft all around. A little bit more Saaz presence would not hurt at all, but still a solid beer. Better than drinking Port Mahon’s insipid Greene King ales...
I love this beer. It is a great all around pils and I love the fact that you can get a really good beer that is also mass-produced and available in supermarkets
Bottle @ Gingerman, Austin. This is probably the best thing to happen to the Budweiser name. Sour, malty, grainy.
If they have been brewing this beer for 700 years who am I to judge? Time tells, it is , golden lager.
Pale golden czech pilsen. Herbal, grainy aroma. Outstanding malt and mouthfeel, only moderate bitterness. Quite subtle but still complex. An old but dear friend.

Great beer. Sampled in the US after someone told me the history behind it. An excellent brew with a great appearance and a great taste. Goes down very smoothly and has a great long lasting taste. Amazingly better than the other one.
Nice golden coloured beer with a good white head. Refreshing, one of the best pilsners around. (Bottle  33cl)

Bottle. Clear golden with a medium white head. Pleasant hoppy aroma. Medium bodied. Flavor starts malty sweet and then evolves into great hop bitterness. Tastes very fresh despite of the green bottle. A very good pilsner!
pretty good beer, i’ve had a few of these in my time.  The Czechs realy come through with this brew

Tasted in my Pilsner Urquell flute glass. It pours a crystalline golden colour, with a nice white head that dosn’t last long and leave almost no lace. Smell of herbs, sweet perfumed herbs, and grains, with some earthiness.
Flavor of herbs, not as bitter as Urquell, but a very good bitterness, grains. Mouth feel is crispy and carbonated and a bit grassy. This is the real deal budweiser folks.
Edit from 2019, first one on 2007.
Embarrasing to say, this is what Budweisser is supposed to be.  Deep golden poor with large white head, slightly fruity and an almost oily quality.  Excellent Pilsner

Pours a golden color with a white head.  Aroma is of some grassy tones, slight floral hops, and some sweet malts.  Flavor is thicker then most pilseners with grassy tones and floral hops.  More flavor then any pale lager here in the US, but still not that much.  This brew is ok but nothing I will drink much of again.
(Czechvar, in the green bottle sold in the US) Very enjoyable. Nice fresh lager with balanced flavor stimulating palate.
Sharp bitter taste in front and smooths at the end.  Golden colour with mild hops & malt aroma.  Not impressed with this but do like it better than the St. Louis Budeweiser.
Great pils.   seems to have a mellow malt under-taste that most pils dont have, makes for a full aftertaste.  aroma is heavy skunk.
This is a pretty good beer - everything that Heineken, Bud America and Carlsberg with they were. Heavier than the usual crap on tap, this is really refreshing with a strong taste and lovely head.

12 oz. bottle - Pours a clear golden color with a one finger thick white head.  Slight lacing.  Aroma is light skunk, grain, and grassy hops.  Flavor is grain (corn) and grassy hops.  Light to medium body.  A very nice lager.  Probably the best Pils I’ve had.  Nice beer.

Good example of what golden lager should be. Very drinkable and refreashing, but not as horribly bland as its namesake and other offenders. More malty then other Czech Pilsners like Urquell, but with a crisp Saaz hop flavour to balance

500 mL bottle from LCBO.



App.:  medium golden with a reasonable foamy, white head. 
 
Aroma:  green, herbaceous hops, a bit of sweet malt behind that and a bit of cereal.  

Palate:  medium body and med-low carbonation.  

Flav.:  candy malts, a touch of cotton candy, more malt and cereal to finish with a bit of hops.  Almost no bitterness.
My sweatheart, my friend, a beer for real man only. Fantastic hoppy aroma that last really long.
Bottle. This is a super beer of it’s type a  real classic. Would love to try a draught.

12 oz bottle via LS. Pours a clear golden color with an averaze size white head. Lots of effervescant bubbles shoot from the bottom the Pilsner glass for a long while. Nose is mellow with just some floral hops and a bit of lemon. Taste is a bit bland, but there are more malts and hops here thani most pale lagers. And the toasted grain aftertaste is plesant. High carbonation. Light/medium body. Pretty good for what it is.
Creamy white head, nice golden colour, malt nose, some bitter taste, nice body. For me this is the real one, Much, much better than the "brew" from the other side. :-)

Slightly skunky aroma but also a nice cereal grainy character. Nicely balanced with a rise in hop bitterness at the very end of the swallow. Malt character is very grainy. Pours a light amber with a very weak white head and no lacing. Active carbonation makes the mouthfeel sprightly. A fine summer BBQ beer.

With the exception of its initially overpowering ultra-skunky aroma, I thought this was a rather good Bohemian Pilsner/Czech lager.  However I still prefer Pilsner Urquell to this beer.

When I opened this beer, my wife (the non-beer drinker in the house) immediately asked if I smelled skunk.  Upon opening the bottle, the methyl butyl thiol smell was overpowering - worse than any beer I’ve ever opened before.  And this was a from a bottle with an expiration date of July 2007!

Oddly, the skunkiness seemed to retreat a bit after the beer sat in the glass a few minutes, and wasn’t really reflected in the taste (unlike Beck’s, which I believe relies on skunkiness for much of its aroma and taste profile).  Flavor was much like Pilsner Urquell:  Saaz hops with a pleasing, rich balancing malt character.  Mouthfeel was unremarkable.  Appearance was beautiful - sparkling gold with a fluffy white head.

With the considerable exception of the horrible smell that greeted me when I opened this supposedly-fresh bottle, I thought this was a pretty good beer.

This is the real thing. Pours with a big fluffy white head, which doesn’t last as long as I expect, but still leaves a nice lace. Crystal clear. Wonderful smell of malt and hops. Excellant balance of both - but the hops are there, don’t worry. Full mouthfeel, but not chewy - just right. Pilsener lovers heaven!

something about this beer that i love.  i would have to say the balance of hop and malt is perfect - feels perfect every drink.  Other than this great quality, there is nothing extra special about this beer, but it’s very good

Golden color with a medium head.  Aroma is full of grains and has an earthiness to it.  The taste is pretty much the same.  Moderate hop flavor.  There are other choices for best Pilsener, but this is a good stand by for sure.

Very nice earthy, grainy nose.

This is a very nice crisp and refreshing Pilsner, but the flavor profile is a little watered down compared to some of the other Pils I have had.  Very nice, but give me Urquell any day

Best buy 8/2006, so I’ll have to rerate this one later.  Yellow, slightly gold, clear with a foamy, loose white head, dissipating rapidly.  The nose has a little skunk, but that seemed to clear once it was open for a bit.  Spicy hops, a light toastiness, hay, a little bread.  The mouthfeel is a bit fizzy, but not too much, and creamy for a lager.  The flavor is a cut above and tastes relatively fresh.  Spicy lively hops with a bit of caramel sweetness and slight toast, but very clean and crisp.  Creamy finish, with a little spicy hop bite in the aftertaste.  Benefit of the doubt not included, this gets a 3.3, I’ll try it again when I catch a fresh one!

Bomber, best by date 03/07:  Dark, clear, straw color with amber tint.  White head with a merange-like quality to it.  Floral, piny hops, clay-like mineral, and malty sweetness in the aroma.  One in the mouth, I found this just plain bad.  Mineral-like bitterness started this beer, followed by a maltiness that included a quality that I can best describe as morning breath.  Then the spicy hops balence out the flavor, until the lasting finish of more morning-breath like quality, with notes of licorice.  This had to be a bad bottle, I might have to take Real Ale Dave’s advice, and buy a closed case...

I’ve reviewed and rereviewed this beer (on BA at the time), but I’ve finally gotten it figured out, so I nuked the previous reviews and rest on this one, which is consistent with my experience over my last three cases (yea, cases - what?) of this beer. First, the review, then the secrets.

Deep gold, more than two or three fractions darker than most Czech pils. Bright white head, that never seems to stay around that long.

Nose is deep, soft, sweet crackery maltiness perfectly mixed with spicy slightly grassy Saaz. Tiniest touch of sulphur. So simple, yet so compelling. Utterly irresistable to this drinker.

Full side of medium in the mouth, with a slight sweetness leading the way. This quickly gives way to a rich, soft maltiness. The spicy hop flavor comes on in the mid-palate, seamlessly blending with the malt. Incredibly long finish that gently sees the hops move to the fore, and it is their bitterness that ultimately ends things. Sheer perfection.

Mouthfeel is so soft - the beer glides into every nook and cranny. I could easily accidently drown myself in this one, and all I’d have is a big stupid grin on my face. God beer when it’s on.

So, here are the secrets: (1) only buy closed cases, or, if buying less than a case, from a closed case, as it gets light struck easily; (2) the cases, but not the six packs or bottles have a best before date - the beer is as described above during the last three months preceeding the best before date and about one month after - too early and it’s a bit coarse, too late and the hops don’t properly balance it; (3) only buy from retailers who care about their stock and have not kept it somewhere warm; and (4) don’t buy it in the summer, unless you know your distributor and retailer keep things at the proper temperature as it heat damages easily. A PITA? Yep, but well worth the effort in my book, and much cheaper than a trip to the Czech Republic (no matter how lovely that would be . . .).
nice whitish tan head, moderate life.  One of the best lagers I have had.  The sweet malts are nicely countered by floral hops.

Bottle from Hy-Vee poured into flute @ 52 degrees...a little warm for a pilsner - Pours clear gold with a fizzy white 1 finger head; Malt mostly with a trace of hops to the nose; Pilsner malts on the initial taste; A yeasty aftertaste with a bit of a grassy note; At 57 degrees there was almost a sugary sweetness in the aftertaste; Medium to watery body; Decent carbonation; This was ok. Not great, but ok. Good imported lawnmower beer.

Bottle, Students’ Association, St Andrews. Slightly floral aroma,bitterness, perhaps a dash of malt at the end of the nose. Mouth is tasty, lots of herby hops, sweetness of malt, but malt taste not there itself. Very clean, easy to drink. Little too gassy. Clean on the palate, nice lasting bitterness. OK, I suppose.

Best by date of March 2007, Sampled January 2007

Topped by a fluffy, two-finger thick, pale tan toned white head that is fairly large bubbled.  The beer is a brilliantly clear, copper hued, full gold color.  The aroma has a sweet malty note to it up front that has touches of toffee to it, but finishes off with a nice biscuit malt aroma.  The hop aromatics seem to have faded a bit compared to the fresher examples of this that I have had in Germany (but that was years ago), but there is a touch of spicy hop aromas here in the middle.  Notably a touch of grassy hops mixes in with the malt notes and a touch of herbal is just perceptible.



The beer is quite a bit drier than I was expecting from the nose and has a nice solid bitterness to it that starts as a nice hop bite in the beginning.  In fact the hops are much more prominent in the flavor than in the aroma; here the grassy, almost hay like hop character looms quite large in the flavor profile.  There is a touch of herbal lemon character (sort of like lemon grass or maybe even lemon thyme), especially in the finish where a light tartness seems to magnify it a bit.  Just a hint of diacetyl seems to round out the malt components; it seems to add a touch of toffee to the finish.  The finish also has a nice solid bitter note to it that lingers a bit on the tongue.  All in all this is a nice beer, while the aroma was not quite as fresh as I remembered, the flavor was still nicely tasty.



Purchased: Plaza Liquors, Tucson, AZ

Pours a fizzy deep gold, topped by half an inch of frothy white foam. The head reduces to a film and a ring in a minute or so. Decent enough lacing. Sweetish aroma from a distance, a little grain and spicy hops are prominent when held closer to the nose.

Smooth and mellow sweet malt - not quite sugary, not quite a honeymalt. Good balance from the spicy hops. A little on the light side, very softly carbonated, but still a nice quenching brew.

My first bottle of this was brought back from the Czech Republic by a friend. My second time I had this was discount cans of this bought in the Jewish Quarter in Paris. I toured the brewery I drank from the bright tanks on a private tour of the brewery and I agree this is one of the best light lagers in the world.Page 89 of Michael Jackson’s Great Beer Guide and only 446 beers left in the book.
Pours a golden yellow with thin head.  Nice hop/malt aroma.  Nice bite with spice and orange flavors.  Good carbonation and excellent mouthfeel.  Recommended for its price.
Bottle. Creamy white good mostly lastinge head. Yellow colour. Nice but a little bready aroma. Moderate bitter nice flavor. Average finish. Creamy palate. Good stuff.

Beautifully clear with white head.  Aroma is of Saaz hops and malt with  just a slight skunkiness.  Flavor is of rich malt balanced nicely by spicy Saaz hops and just a hint of sulphur and skunk.  A well balanced very nice example of a bohemian pilsner

Dark golden body with nice bubbles. Generous amount of bubbly off white head. toasted bread and floral notes.  Flavor was same with an bright finish. Bit richer than your typical pils but still refreshing.
Poured golden with a quickly diminishing head.  Hops come out right away.  Smooth, well balanced beer. I liked it better than Pilsen Urquell 15 years ago, but I´m not so sure now.

Bottle. Clear yellow colour with a mddium mostly diminishing white head. Rich aroma and taste of malts and hops. Bitter finish. Much better than the so called "real" budweiser. this is actually recommendable.

Mybe the .5l bottle was a bit skunked but I remember this beer to be better back in 92.  The beer of kings is head and shoulders better than the "king of beers" but that’s not saying much. Rich golden color with aromatic head which settled moderate. Nice malty body with expected czech hoppiness scale. A good hitchhiking soda. (2.9)

re-rate 6/18/07 Draft, bottle and Can on Beer trip #2.  Refreshing to have it at their resturants in Prague and Bratislava.  Aroma flavor and overall upped.  Served with gusto in appropriate glassware in all pubs.Seems to be an industry wide push there, down to the sparkling water glasses with the correect logo opn them. a far cry from the commie days of chipped beer mugs.
Re-rate on re rate day 02/29/2008:  The planing is going like water going downhill for the second trip to the beer holyland.....Czech Republic.  That’s sayin soethin since I’m Slovak. Body is light and crisp out of the 11.2 oz export bottles, but overall that is a minor detail.  Murky nose needs to be pulled from the bottle, as it does not wish to be separated from the body.  I dont blame it. this is one of my favorite lagers. it is great in this bone chilling cold and still light enough that I can type well after four of them.  Even Ogreface’s comments seem to make sense (even for a  Hungarian) Man o man this is a great brew.

12 oz bottle.  Clear yellow orange.  Barely any white head remains after the initial froth.  Lemon candies, limeade and yeast.  Watery lemon apricot, minimal carb.  Light drying with an aftertaste of well-chewed, stale bubblegum.

Bouteille verte, de 500 ml, achetée à la LCBO (Toronto, ONT). Arôme: Odeur de malt et d’houblon. Apparence: La couleur est blonde dorée avec une faible densité de bulle. Présence d’un moyen col mousseux et d’une fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût fruité. Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement huileuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de fruité en arrière goût. (Rating #808)
Pours a clear yellow color.  Aroma of grain, grassiness, sweet malt and hops. Taste is the same with high amounts of carbonation and a clean finish.
Fine hop aroma and taste. Had more body than Pilsner Urquell. In green bottle rather than brown bottle shown.

A good solid beer, good for a major Czech brewery. However, does not leave a patch on many other Czech macro beers - including Urquell which has far more depth to it.
I notice how it has labels advising to serve cold - and after having a few of these, I can see why - the bottom of the bottle always comes through with some not so pleasent aftertastes. 
What I want from a Czech Pils is a fresh, ’green’ taste to it, with some good hoppyness - lacks a little in that, although the maltyness is nice and well balanced.

Pours golden with a two finger head.  Aroma is of both malt and hops.  You can taste a little bit of grainy malt and of course the hops.  Overall pretty good beer.  Too bad it can’t go by it’s real name here.

Light gold colour. Head quickly settled to light lacing. Nice soft saaz, low malt. 
Good balanced beer with moderate bitterness. Clean flavour, no noticeable faults.
A rich golden color, like most pilsners.  Very hoppy, with little other flavoring, though it smells of malt.  Good for a pilsner, but it is a pilsner so is rather boring nonetheless.

Bottle. Golden colour with a nice big average lasting head. Bit malty aroma with good hoppiness. Aroma is clear and tasty of malts, hops, nice sparkling on the tongue. Great beer and it is the true KING OF BEERS compared to another poor beer of (unfortunately) same name.
A decent pilsner...smooth, aromatic, just not at the same level as Pilsner Urquell.  Enjoyable, and always a welcome pilsner
A refreshing little guy.  A really cold bottle of this is certainly nothing to complain about.
A great tasting beer for sure, smooth and biting but not quite as good at the Pilsner Urquell.  Also, a bit overpriced here in the states :(
Pale golden color with medium head. Hoppy aroma with a similar taste. Very smooth, but as far as Czech lager go, I prefer Pilsner Arquell slightly.

It’s interesting how one’s tastes change. At one time I thought this was one of the best beers going. I hadn’t had any for some time and last weekend I bought a sixer. I still like it but not anywhere as much s I did. I certainly is a good representative of pilsners but somehow I am not as high on pilsners as I once was. A little to light, a bit too hoppy, and I have gotten away from liking as much royal hops as once did.

It’s a decent beer but net al all one of my favorites

A good beer!  A nice pale amber colour and a hoppy hoppiness of taste.  Quite why this little baby leant its name to that American filth, I do not know!  If there was a game of chess between this fellow and its Yank namesake, it would be "Czech" mate to this boy all day!!!
A great pilsner, but I’ve always preferred the pilsner urquell. Looks great with a good deal of carbonation, goes down smoothly but the finish is a little bitter
Nice slightly bitter hoppiness and a little butter and caramel. Full and almost creamy mouthfeel. Not as bitter as Urquell. Goodie.

Bottle. Light, floral aroma, smells of apricots. Gold color, a bit darker shade than I anticipated. Sparkling, slightly hazy appearance. Subdued malt, fairly strong hop flavors. Very satisfying and drinkable, but not special. Fairly typical taste for a Czech, but not the most flavorsome example of the style. Very crisp to the palate, not as light in body as one would expect from most golden lagers. Good, slightly bitter aftertaste. Solid beer across the board. Czechvar is a nice change of pace from its ubiquitous rival Pilsner Urquell, but I still tend to prefer the latter.

An excellent beer. It is ironic that the Czech Republic is one of the few countries where some of the best beers there are also the most popular. Well, maybe it is not ironic per se, actually it makes sense. This beer is extremely smooth, but at the same time flavourful. It is something that you can turn around in your mouth and enjoy, then swallow with glee. You can swill it or sip it and it is still great. Nice golden colour. Refreshing and crispy like a bag of Doritos.

if i was asked to descibe this beer in one word it would be MILD.  It’s pleasant and keeps its head longer than most pilsners, but is not all that great.  The aroma is hoppy and definetly smells like a pils, but does not have alot to offer in the palate just hoppy, dry, crisp and easy to drink (but it is pleasant).  I’ll drink it again but, Pilsner Urquell is a much better buy

From the bottle pours a light clear straw color with a thin white head. Grassy hops in the nose, very crisp. Very quenching beer, light and crisp. Hops are a bit spicey and provide a sharp and crisp finish.

Very nice gold color, but I was disappointed the head faded so quickly. Faint lace. Interesting aroma; reminds me of honey-smoked turkey. Nice malt flavor, but an even more appealing bitterness in the end. Nice carbonation.

Complex malt with Sazz hop noble flavor. Falvor is of complex malt and high floral bitternes from Saaz hops slight Diacetyl. Bitterness does not linger nor is this beer astringent. Very plae gold and very clear with firm head. Medium body and meduim carbonation.
Bottle. Nice golden color and frothy head. Crisp taste. Very good pilsner. One more reason why the Czechs love their beer.
Crisp clean refreshing. Color of staw and pale yellow. Nothing special. Had 2 and moved on.
On tap in Plzen. Really refreshing. Nice fruit and grain flavours. Not as bitter as Urquell, or at least a nicer type of bitterness.

I first fell in love with Budweiser Budvar while I was in Austria for 3 months in the Fall of 2000.  I have even been through the town of Budejovice in the Czech Republic on rail, but unfortunately I did not get a chance to stop by the brewery.  I was so happy when this beer finally made it to the USA as "Czechvar" in 2001/2002.  Needless to say I have had many bottles of this great beer over the years, but now it is finally time to rate it...

Czechvar is clear golden yellow.  Moderate carbonation with a big, foamy white/ivory head.  Aroma is malt and crisp, floral/grassy Saaz hops.  Flavor is true Pils all the way - A little malty, floral/grassy Saaz hops, and a distinctly sharp bitterness that’s so good!  The beer is on the lighter side, but does have some body to it.  It is crisp and clean on the tongue and very smooth.  Actually, I think this particular bottle is a bit more mellow than usual...

I love this beer and will take a bottle Budweiser Budvar (Czechvar) over Pilsner Urquell anyday!

0.5 L brown bottle (best before 08/2006), $1.99 from the Dilly Deli.

Bottle.Pours like a typical pilsener with the honey golden yellow and white head.Aromas of wet grass and malt with a sweet malt and slight bitter hops.This beer is similar to Pilsner Urquell but costs $3 more so I will go with Pilsner Urquell when I want this flavor.

500 ml bottle:  I took extra effort to reach to the back middle of the shelf to get one that was stored in the dark and then stuck it in the dark until a drank it.  Pours into the class a rich golden color with big airy head.  aroma is has got some nice grassy earthy hops and cereal type malt.  Flavor is much of the same.  nice hoping and good malt.  bitters nicely in the finish.  really nice pils.
Bottle.  Clear yellow golden body with a frothy white head.  Aroma is a bit skunky with some yeast.  Flavor is light and lemony, very dry.  A good pils, but not my favorite style.
Bottle.  Pours clear golden with a white head.  Taste of sweet malt and a few hops.  A good pilsner.  I think I just prefer ales.
Quite a typical pils,  dry dry dry with a champagne like tongue.   Slight skunky smell (honestly I don’t know why people love pils so much - ales have so much more flavor!)
Pours a watery gold with a decent white head. A little sweetness. Alright for what it is, but I’d rather drink a Grain Belt if I’m drinking this type of beer.

One of the best beers I’ve ever had. It’s really upsetting how poorly Budweiser did in replicatiing this great beer. Amazing full taste, no sour or bitter aftertaste. A great beer, if you can find it.

Bottle (330ml) and Tap. One of the beers i have drunk most in my life. The reason is not that  i am the biggest fan of it, but simply you can find it everywhere. Anyway, i really like it and i am more than glad to drink it

Clear straw color, tight white head that last.  Aroma has some skunkiness but also some hoppiness.  Flavor is very clean with sharp bitterness in the finish.  Palate is very light.  No aftertaste.  Overall, a decent summer drinking beer.  It has some hop to it but is very clean and light.

29-09-2006, this was properly the best lager that I have ever tasted. Carlsberg and Tuborg just don’t reach the amazing aroma of this beer. Overall a nice sweet and very drinkable lager with a slight note of bitterness that is well balanced. All together a great Lager. Pored from draft at Ølbaren

Golden with an initially fluffy white head.  Sweet malt, some hops and skunk (green bottle) aroma.  Flavor is a bit sweet and grainy.  Light hops in the finish.  Great history and I love the way they fight against AB.
Nose of a little grainy malt and very little hops; gold with a small white head; flavor of some sweet malt with a tiny hop finish. Bottle says best by 02/2006 so hops may have faded.

This had an average head.not much aroma.light amber color.had an overall taste like one of those crappy beers, aka Schitz Malt liquor,but not quite as bad.Rather light.Looks clean and crisp,but doesn’t taste that great.Would rather buy something else,like Stone’s IPA.

(2006).  This isn’t a bad beer, but isn’t my favorite Bohemian lager by a long way.  Nice aroma with hits of saaz comin’ atcha. A nice, if bit pale, yellow, clear appearance.  Drinkable.  A little thin on the palate.  Fizzy.

This beer is becoming more widely available here in New Zealand and has done over the last year that it has been distributed by Dominion Breweries. Usually anything they touch turns to offal, however this pilsener is the exception. My only complaint about this good looking, full flavoured lager is that there wasn’t enough aroma of its reknown Saaz hops. However the pleasant lingering after-taste more than makes up for this minor gripe. A beer to come back to regularly.

Bottle, 50cl. Poured clear golden, with high carbonation and a frothy white head. Malty aroma, backed with heavy, grassy hops. The flavour is of strong, quite metallic hops, with the aftertaste turning into a lasting bitter malt. Classic pilsener taste. Excellent palate - not too watery, which seems a problem with many pilseners, but very refreshing. This is better when your drinking it off tap in Prague, but the bottle does the trick....Recommended pilsener, and increasingly available in the UK.
Bottle. Dark golden with a light coppery shade. Full of large bubbles, fine head. Wonderfull Zatec (Saaz) hop bouquet. Flavour is hop, grass, with a taste dominated by hops.
Light and only slightly better than the American version of Budweiser.  Nothing to write home about.
Bottle. Tasted it together with a border-beer (lawn-beer) trying to get my neighbor drinking quality beer. It succeeded, because this beer contains lots more of what a beer normally ought to contain.

Green 500 mL bottle.  Light orange, with a bit of head.  Smell is not unpleasant: a hint of malty sweetness, a hint of citrus, and a bit of freshly cut timothy.  Smells like candy when it warms.  I like the taste much more than I do most pilseners.  Fairly sweet.  Very clean, with just the right amount of carbonation.  Underneath is the pilsener taste (maltiness) I don’t much like.  Lovely bitter finish.  Good stuff.

Had to revisit this one. AB had a "sample the brands" at the brewery HQ for employees and contactors (me), the other day.

Poured nice pale gold, citrusy/hop aroma. 

Taste had a hint of seet, follwed by a shot of hps, and malt. 

Finishes crisp, and very, very good.

Not much a trace of skunk, as I had on the previous review..might be because of the AB distrubution? Most likely fresher than the sample I had before.
My all time favourite.I actully prefer bitter to lager and weissebeers but had to try the legend in the land of its birth.I wasn’t disappointed

After a day sampling various German pilsners in Germany, I thought I’d compare them with "the real thing" - and it is. Pours a golden colour with a white head. A powerful scent, hard to describe, but one I associate with Czech lagers, and French pissoirs. A powerful flavour that invades the mouth, sweet but balanced with a powerful blast of hops. Overall a stunning pilsner.

Bottle. Poured a golden yellow with an impressive, thick, solid head. Scent is somewhat sweet, with some hop notes poking out. Taste is clean, a little too skunky for my liking, but very smooth. There seems to be inconsistences from bottlings as I’ve tried it a few different times with varying levels of skunkiness.

Perhaps something went wrong with my bottle on its way here to Panama. It was labelled "Duty Free". Poured into the glass with essentially no head and very little carbonation. Flavor was for a Pilsener, not that memorable. But better than typical macrobrew fare.
Fantastic lager tastes great not to much co2 looks appetising generally great all-round beer.
Large bottle, hot summer day, great beer. Certainly worth the hype when measured against the standard ’Budweiser’. Relative to other premium lagers I would say it holds its own.

Green 12 oz bottle.  Had to try the "famous budweiser beer."  Poured light golden, head disappearing immediately.  Aroma initially of strong bologna skunkiness (green bottle disease), settling into familiar saaz hop and grain/straw pils aroma.  Flavor of lemony hop, wet grain, grass, with a bit of a sulphury finish.  Watery palate, flattened out very quickly.  Though not entirely offensive, I expected a lot more.  I’d definitely take Pilsner Urquell over this if given the choice between the two.

0.5 L bottle, bottled in June 06. Dark golden with a light coppery shade. Full of large bubbles, fine head. Wonderful Zatec (Saaz) hop bouquet. Full-mouth, velvety mouthfeel, with a taste dominated by hops.
Bottle.  Golden colour. Aroma of vanilla and rich biscuity malt. Hoppy flavor. Juicy malt. Not very bitter, but dry finish.

1)Wildly effervescing golden trumpet. Citrussy hop aroma. That abruptly rubbery Saaz dryness. Bitterly simplistic, and not a patch on the dark version. 635413.
2)Re-rate over 8 years later...Waft of hutch from a mile off. Bready and honey-dripped with suggestions of cashew almost in the GA ballpark. Crisp suck of bitterness to conclude. Clean, refreshing and clearly a cut above most of the other rubbish available in Hinckley TossCo. 737314.

This is the first beer that I have encountered from this brewer. Sampled from a 16.9 oz brown bottle this beer poured a medium golden color with a huge soapy off white head. The aroma is sour macro lager. The flavor is typical tangy macro lager with very little body or character. Typical crappy macro style beer. Totally forgettable.

Bottle. Pours out a nice golden colour with a playful bubbly white head. Scent is very skunky with light metallic notes. Taste is yeasty with very light fuity notes hanging on the backdrop. Leaves a slight bitterness on the palate. Unexpected flavour elements that seem to have two distinct layers of flavor... One initially yeasty with hanging fruitiness and two a bitter hoppiness with citrus notes. Overall smooth on the mouth and mild bodied.

pale golden color
white head not very long lasting
smells malty,sweetish,but rather hoppy too,has a hidden sweat-like smell
middle carbonated
tasts malty , less sweetish than it smells and hoppy, some citrus
aftertaste malty,a bit honey-like and a hoppy finish, with some bitterness in the end
more interesting than much other beers of that style, rather hoppy,interesting honey-note ,but could have a bit stronger smells and tasts

Bottle.  Budweiser anyone?  Come on though, its not that bad.  enjoyed my bottle with a perfectly made peanut butter and jeely sandwich.  I don’t think it gets any better than this - no wait, thats Genny.
smells like a pilsener.  not super saaz hopps bitterness which is nice.  good, but only for a pilsener.

Bottle 43F Lager Glass.  Strong aroma some skunk and decent hops, not to bad overall yet skunk was prominant.  Light fluffy head that was nicely thick with nice clear golden color.  Decent hops flavor, but very light on hte tongue, good beer easy to drink nice and refreshing a nice pilsner, if only the american budwiser was simiar.
tap. pale clear yelllow color. typical factory pilsner with a bit of spice. nasty.

Pours golden with little carbonation and healthy white head.  Aroma is fairly skunky malt - could be worse though.  Medium body with carbonation right between soft and fizzy.  Taste has lots of smooth malt - there is still some skunk funk, but not as much as on the aroma.  Finish hits with a fair amount of hops that are surprisingly pleasant.  The skunk actually fades away a bit as you get further down the glass.  An okay beer, but the legend and story is far more intersting that the actauly product.

bottle, labelled "Duty-Free Only"  Sweet, floral aroma.  The color was gold with hints of red, and a nice white head.  The flavor was a little bit grassy, but not in an off-putting way, it was sweeter than that.  The mouthfeel was light.  Overall, this was a nicely refreshing beer.
Half-liter bottle pours golden with a lasting white head.  Very well balanced, hearty, refreshing. Excellent pils.

Fellow, ratebeerians, this bud’s for you.  Seriously, it’s the only thing remotely drinkable with the word "Budweiser" on the lable (due to the fact that it has no relation with anheuser-busch).  The reason it said "budweiser" on the label and not "czechvar" is because deltamarik was nice enough to bring me a bottle directly from the Czech Republic.

This beer has a wonderful hopps aroma and a distinctly clean mouth feel.  Unlike american brews sporting the name "pilsner" it fininshes clean with residual hopps versus a grainy corn-like residue that leaves you wondering why you just did that to yourself.  Man, that was good.

I’m half Czech, so Czech beers will always be my standard.  Is Budvar my favorite beer?  No.  But it (along with Pilsner Urquell) is the standard that all else should follow.  It’s not like an Imperial Stout or a Tripel- it’s just a basic beer done really, really well.  No weaknesses to speak of.  Residual hops after you’re done drinking.  One of the best beers to have with a meal.  A bit expensive in the states, but if you don’t like this, you don’t like beer.  Oh, and extra points for sticking it to Anheuser-Busch.
Bottle. Golden beer with a white head. Aroma is fruity malt. Flavour is fruity malt . OK pilsner.
A very nice Czech pils that, I have to agree with others here, I like better than  Pilsner Urquell.  (500ml bottle)
This is what A-B’s Bud would be if they knew what beer was supposed to be. A very good beer. I will buy more of this to keep my fridge stocked. Sweet, hoppy. slight head.
Really nice on a warm day, don’t feel like a long comment but I do like Pilsner Urquell more, this one needs more hops i think.

Part of a mini Czech Pilsner taste-off. Surprising to me, I preferred this over Pilsner Urquell. Liked the aroma better. Crystal golden, balanced bitterness with  medium malt body. I preferred Limburg Czechmate, a NZ interpretation of this style...just!.. freshness no doubt played a part.

500ml bottle sampled with Finn at Cafe Ida-Sofie, Kilpis in Finnish Lapland 15.07.2006. Golden in colour with almost no foam. Pleasant malty aroma. Medium palate. Flavour with hints of fruit and malt. Short bitter end. Quite well balanced. Worth another try sometime (see Finn for the state of the beer).

Re-rate: Bottle 0,5l bought at Kilpisjärvi. (Bottles lately observed in Tromsø!) Golden colored. A good-looking creamy head. Hoppy aroma with some malt. Inviting. Very soft mouthfeel. Well rounded flavor with malt in the foreground but also some fruit. Dry bitter aftertaste that lasts. Very moreish. KI=3
Old rating: 4-3-4-3-8=2.2 :Bottle 0,5l. Sampled together with Rune at Ida-Sofie restaurant in Kilpisjärvi, Finland 15 Jul 06. Pretty brown colour. A rapidly disappearing head. Some sweetness. Gives a rounded impression with some sweetness. A bit too carbonated. The beer was probably not at it’s best: Used in a display of available beers behind the counter - and outdated. Must try to find it again. KI=3
clear yellow with white head. Aroma  and taste of sweet malts & pilsner malts. Little fruityness, some hops. Pleasant finish. Overall above average lager! Grassy and crisp. Rerate Nov. 09

Bottle. Pours a clear, very bubbly gold with an average size semi-lasting off-white head. Decent aroma of sweet malt, grain, fruit and hops -- surprisingly, no skunkyness. Flavour follows the aroma but is a touch too sweet and a little watery. Light to medium bodied. Nothing great but better then I expected and one of the better Euro Lagers I’ve tried.
Overall a pretty run of the mill lager, but much better than the american counterpart.

Wow.  Drank this while in Prague. What in the world happened to the US version of this great beer?  Clear yellow, and nice clean had.   Malt and hops, but perfectly balanced.    The slight sweetness and good use of hopping make this really good pils.  Very nice to drink.
Yellow with white top. Taste of sweetish malt (and suprisingly much of it) and lots of bitter hops. Nicely balanced indeed. Aroma is hoppy. Great beer. And Czech!

500ml Bottle, 5% a/v
Smells of grains with a slight hop tinge. The taste consists of hops and malt, nicely balanced. The aftertaste is largely malt which slowly fades. Not a bad beer really.
