Green bottle, 500ml from LCBO nice golden Euro Pilsner, great head (wish it lasted longer though), and decent  malty/floral aroma. Superb malt/hop balance - the subtle sweetness and slight lingering bitterness makes this a great Bohemian.  **RE-RATE: fresh batch at LCBO, bought a bunch on sale. Knocked up a couple points. Must say again, really good beer**
The original Budweiser. Much better than the American Bud. This is much better overall. A little maltier and hoppier and cleaner taasting.

Bottle. Medium head with medium duration. Color is light golden. Aroma is a bit stronger than the average lager and is mainly hops and malt. Taste is hops with some malt and a a slightly bitter finish.
Great hop profile in this one, balanced by the slight sweetness. A great example of a Czech pils, a classic, I haven’t tryed this one in the States yet, but in Europe, its a great drink

Budejovicky Budvar Czech Premium Lager. 500 ml green bottle. Color: a beautiful golden amber. Clear. Large white head that quickly fades away. Sharp aroma with sugars and a little alcohol. Apart from that I don’t know how to describe the aroma. Sweet taste of cookie, and somewhat bitter aftertaste. The balance between the sweetness and the bitterness is exquisite. Watery mouthfeel. A medium level of carbon dioxide. I like this beer.

Poured from bottle (Czechvar).  This is really nice - a pilsener that could be confused with a lager (as I did).  Hop presence in the aroma that almost disappears until the tasting, where it asserts its dominance.  Hops are nor dominant, and do not overwhelm the other qualities of the beer.  Very well made, very enjoyablew brew.

500 ml bottle from la SAQ. Pour a clear golden yellow with a thick white head diminishing quickly.  Aroma is malty, a little herbal and floral. Taste is really well balanced, at first hops are dominating, then malt is showing up just before a somewhat bitter aftertaste. Some floral, honey and citrusy notes. An excellent pils, altough this is not my favorite style.
The original Budweiser.  Much better than the American Bud.  This is much better overall.  A little maltier and hoppier and cleaner taasting.

Bottle from Sainsburys. I had this after my Peruvian Cusquena lager experience. having drank this on numerous occasions, this difference was immediate wonderful golden colour and clear, great crip and refreshing tatse with a good bitterness about it very good beer.

Bottle 16.9 oz. Clear golden yellow w white diminishing head, good carb, min lace. Aroma is that funky mineral water, light dry malt, & skunky Euro in the (brown) bottle hops. Flavor is the same with some spiciness. A bit better tasting, and fuller bodied than Urquell. A touch of soap in the flavor. Dry nicely bitter finish. Every time I start drinking Czech Pils I ask myself: Am I sure I really like this stuff, but after a few mouthfulls I don’t want to stop drinking it.
Wet grassy euro pils nose.  Flavor much the same, light carbination, very little hint of hops.  Not much to add.

Aroma/Malty-light,
Appearance Head/Initial-small, Head/Color white,
Body/Hue-clear,
Initial Flavor-bitter 
Finish Flavor-bitter
Palate/Body-light
beer

(Bottle BB 27/04/07) Slightly hoppy, slightly fruity and slightly malty aroma. Golden colour, slightly sparkling and medium size, white, almost fully diminishing head with very small lacing. Malty, fruity and slightly bitter flavour. Lively carbonated, slightly sticky and medium bodied palate. As a representative of “Bohemian pilsener”, this is rather good brew! 27/05/06

Green Bottle, Very smooth beer, a harmony of light malts and bohemian hops. It is a budweiser made with real and high quality ingredients, very clean and crisp with a light kick of bitterness that goes away in an instant. I wish Bud would by this recipie and mass produce it as is. Its the beer you always want to have in the fridge and that even non-beer geaks will enjoy.

12 oz green bottle:  Wow!  I don’t think this bottle travels well.  Light struck (grocery stores fault, green bottle, under floro lights), smokey and rubbery phenolic (aged w/ yeast), but some lightly floral hops & clean malts(bready, grainy).  Well balanced flavor, mostly to sweet malt, clean grainy flavor w/ some floral/light stuck hops.  Finish is lightly sweet & grainy.  Lighter medium body, medium carb., & smooth.   Overall, probably not a bad beer, but really needs protection from the light.  I blame the store that sells if for that one!!!  Low marks for bad handling!   I know the brewery is not responsible for this, but someone should hear about it!
I am not a huge fan of this style of beer but I would defintly drink this over many other pils, good stuff.

The original budwieser, this beer has  a smooth tase that shouldn’t be avoided. I initially contested whether Czechvar was in fact the north american version, because I believe it to have a slightly different taste. I would say that Czechvar is a little less smooth than Budvar - from memory, it has been a while since I have tasted it. I know that both versions are sold in Scotland and Czechvar is much cheaper than Budvar. If you have the chance to try both - I would recommend you do and comment on any differencence, or not as the case may be.
Skunky, bouqeut like aroma. Golden colored with quickly fanishing head. Amazingly balanced. Hopped to perfection with a smooth dryness and a slight accent of sweet maltiness. Crisp clean finish.
nice pils but can’t measure up to victory or even urquel.  refreshing and predictable, enjoyable.
I’m assuming that most of these reviews are from the bottle, not from a tap in Praha.  This is simply the most delicious beer on the planet when fresh.
Another great example of a pilsner... malty and mildly bitter with hints of sweetness and bread flavor.
Bottled. Pours a golden amber color. Well carbonated. Crisp grainy and malty taste. Grassy scent. Excellent finish. Lives up to its expectation! One of the best pilsners in the world!

The so called "real" budweiser...let’s see:  much fuller nose with a definete lagerness to it.  Slightly fruity and yeasty - fullness that I wouldn’t expect from a budweise-type.  Light, heathery, pleasant.  OK.

I don’t really know why so many people compare this to other swill import lagers like heineken, becks, etc. - this is a wonderfully spicy, floral, buttery pils - medium-bodied, yet really quaffable - just a great pilsner.

On tap at several restaurants in Vienna.  This is an ultimate lager but it counts if you have it from a bottle or draught and if it was handled properly. One can say it is watery and not complex but as long as you need just  a refreshing, cold, golden colored drink with a nice head the Budweiser is unbeatable.
just a bump up from a heineken.  Good, but probably not worth the extra costs to import the stuff.

What can I say? A real pilsner, and the ORIGINAL Budweiser. The only reason its called Czechvar in the US, is because Anhauser-Bush threw a tantrum over the fact that people may confuse this true ’King Of Beers’ over their own mouthwash.

Gorgeous, hoppy, some great bitter depth to it.

Pours a pale golden color with a shallow spritzy froth. Aroma of crisp malt and some hay. Ultra light nectar with ample residual effers. Flavors are light, crisp, and clean with a slight skunkiness on the finish. I detected a little clove somewhere in there. Overall; mow the lawn and have a beer, you’ll never see me drinking this beer.
was my beer of choice in the czech republic. didn’t manage to get to the brewery unfortunately. tastier and more interesting than the pilsener urquel, refreshing and easy to down.

This is a fun beer.  All of the hype isn’t what it deserves, but it is nonetheless a tasty brew.

I’d take Pilsner Urquell over it any day.

Bottled.  Had a bottle of Czechvar and it instantly become one of my favorites, as this is one of my favorite styles of beer.  Surprisingly I didn’t notice any skunk from the green bottle.  I’d recommend this over Heineken, Grolsch or any other green bottled beer any day.

Even though this beer apparently has the kiss of death (Budweiser) it is pretty good for the style.  Pale yellow appearance with a thick white head that is initially respectable but then dissapears leaving nothing but a very little "foam islands" floating around on the top of your beer.  Grassy aroma, a little bread but I’m reaching here, and a bitter wheat/grass flavor.  Dry finish, and I’m finished.

Golden amber in color with a white head. Very sour hops type smell. Started off with a bitter taste of alcohol, but finished with a sweet malt taste. If US Bud tasted this good I would buy it more often!

Pours a bright gold with a decent head that soon fades to a thin meniscus coating.  Aroma of soft floral hops along with wet bread.  Mild Saaz hop bitterness along with floral tones and pale malt sweetness.  Very subtle yet pleasant.  Crisp and Refreshing.
Crystal gold translucence with a short-lived fizzy head.  Smell is sweet and musty.   Flavor is nicely bittered and crisp.  Easy to drink and refreshing if cold enough.

This beer is good, certainly not great.  I think that it is generally overrated.   It seems to me that it has gotten a lot of attention from its legal battles with A-B.  rather flat, very pale.  Light and refreshing, but ultimately forgettable.

Bottle, 33cl. Golden colour with a good but fast-dissipating white head. Not much carbonation. Hoppy and herbal aroma. Flavour is dry and slightly bitter. This is definitely a good pilsner but an average beer. I’d rather have an Urquell.

Øl købt Tyskland (50 cl) 

Øllen er gylden. den har mere smag end en normal pilsner - lidt mere humle. 

Skummet er tyndt hvidt.

Let drikkelig pilsner

Can. Golden beer with a small, white head. Weak, hoppy and malty aroma. The flavor has a nice hoppiness and maltiness. Ok body and a pleasant hoppy finish. Only problem with pilsners is that they are generally quite boring and too quaffable, but this is one of the good ones. Rating: 4-3-4-3-11-2.5. 060411

Bottle. It’s a clear, golden beer topped by a small, white head. It’s rather hoppy on the nose, with a maltyness in the back. Spiced, peppery and slightly grassy, piney hops. It’s malty and dry on the palate, a good bitterness chimes in towards the end. Quite spicy, piney hops. Well, it’s not my favorite pilsner in any way, but it’s straigthforward, quenching and also quite tasteful, so I really don’t know why I’m not drinking more of this. 110827

Clear and pure. Beautiful light colour and nice white head. Not too foamy. A simple and undramatic beer, but the aromatic Saazer hops really make the difference between an ordinary pilsener and this one. The taste doesn’t really stay with you that long, but it’s clean and crisp. The perfect beer for a hot day.

12-oz. bottle.  Pours a bright, shiny gold with a patchy, edgy white head.  Aroma is yeast (sour dough, sweat, earth) and malt (grain), hop notes.  Moderately bitter and acidic, sour and sweaty yeast, grainy malt flavor with a slight sweet finish.  Light bodied and slightly fizzy, clean finish.
A very good pilsener.  What that filthy American swill wishes it could be.  Light with a nice balance.

Draught at "Azza" in Prague, May 2006.
Clear golden color, big white creamy head. Nice hoppy scent. Very hoppy fresh taste. Medium bitterness. Lingering "spicy" hoppy aftertaste. One of the best non-microbrew beers available on tap in Prague!

33 cl bottle from Swedish "Systembolaget" on March 24.Clear golden color with a nice creamy white head. Hoppy and a bit spicy scent, could be from Saaz hops. Good balance of malt and hops in the taste. A great Czech beer indeed.Ar: 7 Ap: 4 Fl: 7 Pa: 3 Ov: 15

Pours a transparent golden color with a fizzy whit head that dissapears fairly quickly. Light malt and hop aroma, nothing fancy, though I wasn’t expecting anything powerful. The flavor is light and crisp...mostly light malt...nothing complex...pretty barebones but in a good session beer kinda way. Light and crisp all the way through to the finish, and super easy to drink. A simple beer, and sometimes that’s what you want.

Can at the Seventh Annual Richmond Beer Dig on 03/08/2009. Very clear golden body with a medium creamy off-white head. Grain and faint honey aroma with some pilsener malt. Sweet honey and pilsener malt flavor. Medium body with moderate carbonation. 7/1/7/3/14 - 3.2

03/25/2006: Clear light golden color with a thin frothy white head. Sweet grainy aroma. Mild sweet grain flavor with some corn hints. 5/2/5/3/10 - 2.5
Gold body with a quickly diminishing white head.  Fair head of hops and some light malts.  Heavy carbonation in the body, hops are evident but also some corn.  Minimal ending.

Bottle. It had a nice transparent gold color, with a nice white head, although a little fizzy, and it diminshed rather quickly, hence the 4/5. The nose was of hops, really harsh, and somewhat metallic.Rather fizzy. It had a slick light bitter and sour feel, not what you would expect of a pilsner. Overall it is a good beer, but not the best pilsner i had
Bottle, 500ml. Small quickly diminishing head. Malty aroma with a moderately bitter finish. Quite fizzy. Not bad at all.

When in germany my buddy ordered this being a bud lover and not being able to find his favorite.  littlle did he know the was not usa bud at all.  a slight malty delight of thiness, but all together not too bad.  better then the us bud for sure!
Much better than American buweiser. Thick head of foam and fruity taste. Not anything too special compared to other pilseners in the Czech Republic.

0.5L Bottle Pour - Clear golden body with white frothy head. Aroma full of hops, grains, and a little fruit. Nice light bitterness leads to a dry finish. Lasting dry but mild enjoyable aftertaste. Quite thin body. Light and refreshing.

Pretty good bohemian pilsener. Subtle golden beer. Frothy head that lasts and lasts. Nose is masterful. Paper thin bohemian bitterness. Slight chalkiness in the hops but mostly a floral, angostura style bitterness. Almost citrus but mostly a thin, lace-like bitterness. Tender. Rasor sharp sweetness that is subdued. Slight straw and sweet biscuit. Flower petal bitterness. Beautiul beer.

1. Can at Derby Square, Liverpool 29/08/2005
Clear golden coloured  and crisp on the palate with a slightly floral aroma. Malty creamy finish with some dryness.
2. 330ml Bottle 20/08/2009
Some carbonation. Malt and hop aromas. Golden coloured hoppy and a little sweet on the palate with a crisp and slightly dry malt finish.
From bottle. light yellow color, with a white head. A mild malt aroma, which suits it well. Fine taste.
Yellow colour with a slight white head. Quite malty for a Czech pilsner but still with the trademark bitterness.
yellow body with a little white head that sat down quickly.sweet malts in the aroma and flavor.medium to light mouthfeel.not to bad i guess.
Sweet grain upfront followed by a substantial hop bite in the middle. Tart notes as well.  Very crisp and dry finish that I find very refreshing.  This should be what domestic macros aspire to be.
Bottle. White head. Clear golden body. Powerful maltaroma. Medium hops bitterness.
Bottle.  Pours a gold color with a small head.  Nice hops aroma.  This actually tastes better than the American Bud.  Nice and crisp....

Pours a clear golden color with a medium sized, lasting head. Aroma is of grains, hay, and hops. Tastes of hops and grass with some citrus as well. Mouth is sorta thin and crisp. Needless to say, this should be the bud for you...

Tastes like no other pilsener. Every time I have drunken this, it has had this strange (not bad) flavour, which I cannot identify. An interesting pilsener, not as refreshing as many others, but funnier.

Poured from the bootle, a carbonated clear straw yellow with no head. An unfortunate (and suprisingly) malty aroma. Some sweetness underlying the flavour (honeyish) and a surprising initial smoothness followed by a pilsener’s usual dry finish (but not too dry). I can see why it is considered one of the better lager-style beers out there.

Sweet and malty.  Heavy.
Not as much hops as I like.
Amber.
Good head.
Flowery smell.

Poured an effervescent golden with a large fluffy white head.  Sweet aroma of caramel, corn, and a touch of grassy hops.  Taste is somewhat lighter than the aroma but pleasant.  Lightly sweet corn and caramel, and the grass hops hit you way in the back.  No real off flavors, and pretty easy drinking.  Unagressive, even bland, but inoffensive.  I would certainly drink this again if someone offered it to me.

Bottle. I seem to remeber this being better than this. Golden, disappearing white head. Lager hop aroma with some citrus. Finish is quite pleasant. But its still a lager. Bit of biscuit.  OK but made me feel bloated. 2.5 Re-rate bottle at home during the Budvar tasting night.  Good lemon slightly syrupy on the malts still

(01.22.06) On tap at Firkin’s, Libertyville, IL. Clear golden yellow Pils lager having a giant white head with good lacing. No discernable carbonation. Sweet malt aroma. Light-to-medium bodied lager that starts with light malt sweetness and light hop bitterness. Finishes dry and clean with a pleasant light corn aftertaste.  Fuller flavor and body relative to a typical American lager such as Budweiser and Miller.  A very good drinkable lager.

(bottle - 12 oz) Light yellow pour with a fizzy white head. Bitter, hoppy aroma with some sour notes and various grains. Flavor begins sweet and grainy with a hoppy middle that cleanses the palate of the initial bitterness and a finish that brings some bitterness and hop flavor back and lets it linger for a time. A bit on the watery side.

The Anheuser Busch Brewing Company of St. Louis, MO proudly calls their Budweiser, The King of Beers, and in one sense, that is true, Budweiser is the world’s largest selling beer. But there is another Budweiser beer, from the Budvar Brewery in the Czech Republic, called Budweiser Budvar, and they call their Budweiser The Beer of Kings. That’s right, thereis another Bud, but this Bud isn’t for you, not if you live in the United States. AB and Budvar have battled this out in court over the years, over the use of the name Budweiser. That has just recently changed, as of 2001, Budweiser Budvar is now on the US market, but under the label Czechvar. 

The American Bud actually came first(AB has been in business longer than Budvar), but the name itself is derived from the town of Budweis, in you guessed it, the Czech Republic. This beer is sold mainly in European countries, where American Bud isn’t sold, but I suspect that has changed. AB has made a big push in Europe as of late, its very popular in Ireland, taps flowing freely next to Guinness. American Budweiser has made it into a number of European markets as B or Bud. My first experience with this beer came in occupied Northern Ireland, I saw it in bottles in a few pubs I visited in Belfast, and later brought some back to the US for future consumption and to share with other beer lovers. Anyone who has seen Michael Jackson’s The Beer Hunter Series knows the story behind this elusive Budweiser. So for a beer lover at the time, this beer was a rare and special treat. 

Budweiser Budvar pours to a deep, bright golden color, with a creamy white head, and a lively carbonation. The nose is very fragrant with that classic Bohemian Red hop aroma, what we know as the Saaz hop. This is a very "fresh cut grass" hop aroma. There is also a good bit of crisp pilsner malt aroma as well, and a touch of DMS(sulphur like aroma). The palate is wonderful. It is firm, crisp, and clean. Really some great malt flavors. The body is smooth and round, this is a very drinkable lager. Budweiser Budvar finishes with some crisp maltiness up front, then leads into a snappy, grassy, bitter hop bite. This is a great drinking beer, very balanced. I’ll take the Beer of Kings over the King of Beers, any day. Expect to pay more for this Bud though, and more than other Czech pilsners on the market, that are of equal, or better quality. This is a great beer, but it has been over hyped, and now that it is here, I suspect the mystique of the "other" Budweiser will wear off. Well worth trying though, and it would match well with chicken or fish.

0.5L bottle I picked up in Berlin.  Pours medium gold, very clear, and with big white head.  A little floral hoppy aroma with slight maltiness.  Nice balance of malt/hops in flavor without the beechwood and formaldehyde of the American imitation.  Also doesn’t seem to have some of the skunk as the other Czech beers (not in a green bottle?).  Quite palatable.
FANTASTIC!!!!! Another wonderful and magnificent brew by the Czech population, they just know how to do it! Refreshing flavour, great.
makes the US budweiser taste this urine, but still lacks an edge to make it a strong success. Decent old czech beer tho.

In a bottle at the Heorot in Muncie, Indiana.  After drinking Delirium Tremens, I tried this, so this might not be entirely fair, but I couldn’t really tell any difference at all between A/B Budweiser and the "original Budweiser."  Pale straw, medium head, not much aroma, very lightly hopped, light grainy taste.  This tasted like a fairly typical overseas premium lager rather than a true Pilsener, but then again, I am also comparing it to Pilsener Urquell.  I didn’t like this as much.  Not enough body or hops to make it interesting to me, although I’m sure it’s a good summer thirst-quenching beer.
"This beer pour out a nice yellow color with just a little bit of head. Has a very nice light hint of hop flavor, nothing special. It did go down smooth, but overall just an average beer.
On tap, in Prague.  This is the way to have this beer.  Crisp golden color,  Small white head.  Not as good as Pilsner Urquell but still quite nice.
Pours with a classic 2 finger head. Fantastic aroma. wonderful taste . When can will it be available on draft?
better than bud a little skunked from the green bottle spicy finish.......nice but pretty boring
Pours a crisp clear golden yellow color with a fizzy white head.  Aromasof hops, grass, and grains.  Flavor is a nice crisp hoppy/grain taste with a nice clean finish.

12 oz bottle pours golden with a short white foamy head.  Aroma is saaz hops and cereal like grains.  Starts off quite sweet.  Frosted flakes is the prevailing first sip taste.  Finished by grassy hops.  Crisp and clean palate with a slightly dry finish.  Carbonated just about right for a pilsener.  A little more tasty than i expected it to be.

Gold in colour and strongly carbonated. Classic saaz hop, sulfur, and light malt aromas... with perhaps a slightly greater leaning towards the malt than other Bohemian pilsners that I’ve tried. Flavor wise, the pilsner malt is quite strong upfront, but the hops take over big time on the back end with lots of grassy flavors and coarse bitterness. Not quite as polished as a non-skunked Urquell, but still pretty good. Thanks Lubiere.

Grainy nose with a light hops presence.  Pours a sparkling blonde with a frothy white head
that is mostly diminishing without much lace.  The brew has good balance with some
sweetness and a light acidity prevailing, and is pretty neutral; but has good flavor for a
lager and a decent finish for the style.  The light and watery body is crisp and clean, with a
slightly dry feel to the finish.

Re-rate:  Bottled.  Bubbly and deep golden.  Wonderful, dark hoppy aroma (Saaz-y!).  Bready.  Sweeter than I remembered, slightly less bitter.  Malty breadiness.  Fat bodied and very drinkable, but I still think it’s overrated.  Will try again on tap.[3.0]

Original: In short, far better than the other Budweiser, the one we all know and hate.  If you’re able to find this, though, you should be able to find better. [2.8]

Got a bottle (Svetly lezak) while in Czech Republic.  Pours clear straw yellow with active carbonation and thin white head.  Aroma of sweet malt, more straw, dust and some light citrus.  Flavor of sweet malt, light citrus.  Thin palate with very active, fizzy carbonation.

Golden with a white head. Heavily carbonated. Aroma is skunky. Good malt body to it. Very light and fizzy on the tongue. The hops are weak and only noticable right away, the flavor then fades into sweet water towards the end.

My Slovak roomate brought me a can from home. I only wish I had this kind of Budweiser at my home. Poured colden with a good with head. Floral aroma with a good hoppy flavor. Compared to the belgains i’ve been drinking, this isn’t too interesting, but it is certainly one of the best lagers I’ve had.

Nice clean flavor, although a bit mild in my opinion; the grassy hops do come through and blends well with the malts. A well made and enjoyable example of this style. Get it in the large 500ml brown bottle as I did.
The best example of a Czech golden beer. You can taste the malt/hop ingredients which is sadly missing from so many ’fast brewed lagers’ I have found it at its best jsut lightly chilled, 12-14^c
The good bud. This one is worth the price. A great refreshment. Tick white head, golden color, floral and grassy aroma. Hoppy flavor. Light beer that goes down well.
The way a bohemian pils ought to look and taste--deep golden in color, dense head, well balanced between crisp hoppiness and lightly sweet maltiness.

Very clear golden yellow with a snow white head.  The aroma is a sweet, but quite clean malt aroma.  Light and crisp pils flavors.  Sweet malts with decent activity.  Not real hoppy, but a mild grassy hop on the finish.  Nice clean beer.

Very light beer, well balanced and refreshing.  No flavors are too overbearing, which is nice, and it has a hint of hoppy finish, also nice.  Tastes a little bit on the watery side though.  Other than that, a very drinkable all-purpose beer.

Bottle Czechvar at Beer Sellar in KY. Pours a clear amber with a moderate white head that diminished slowly. Heavy grass hoppy aroma. Medium body. Good complex hoppy flavor with medium bitter finish of average duration. Very interesting brew.
Best before 9/2005. Oh well. Clear golden body with a puffy head. Grassy hops in the aroma and flavor. Nice smooth beer, but not much here.

That’s good beer, shame it has to share its name with t’other budweiser, this is actually beer flavour. Golden colour, not yellow like most lager, very nice taste, go out and try it. (A-B was actually using the name budweiser about 20 years before these, but this is actually from budweis(budjovice))

Bottle: Poured a golden color pils with a huge foamy head with limited retention. Aroma of grass and floral malt. Taste also include the grass and floral malt and as well as crisp hops thought I was expecting more hops. Body is fuller then expected. Very enjoyable though it seems I could feel that the bottle had travelled a couple thousand miles.

This Czech brew that has been called "Budweiser" throughout Europe since the 13th century, but must be called "Czechvar" in the U.S., due to pressure from its richer (but blander) cousin from St. Louis. Golden pour with a quickly vanishing head.  Very good Pilsner.  Slightly bitter with wonderful hoppyness to it.  This is damn good. Budweiser by Anheiser pails in comparison

As with all Pilseners and other light lagers, one must be careful to assure that the beer is reasonably fresh. Off lavors don’t have much to hide behind. I had my first Budvar in the airport in Frankfurt a number of years ago., and have had it numerous times since. At it’s best, which is how I’m rating it, it is a premier example of what a Pilsener should be. Beautiful clear golden color with a medium white head. Floral hop aroma followed by a light malty feel with some substance. Refreshing astringent light bitterness in the finish . I would love to try it on draft in the Czech Republic.

Sampled this fine nectar from the gods 7/10/05. Pleasant aroma but not over powering. The golden colour looks  very enticing. This crisp easy drinking drop dosent leave you dissappointed. A bit  dry afterwards, but still go back for more.

Agree with most, this is thin and dry.  Mine purchased in Canada had a different label without Budweiser branding.  Simply labelled ’Czechvar’ in same design as sample here.  Cheap price, I got what I paid for.

Bottle. Pours a pale golden with a whispy white head.  Heavily carbonated. Light sweet aroma. Taste is crisp and dry, with a little sweetness. Slightly bitter aftertaste. MUCH better than its American namesake.
(Bottle, best before 1/06) White head, pale yellow body. Slight lacing. Aroma faint honey. Taste a little doughy, otherwise pretty bland. Dry mouthfeel.

Gold with a small head. Lotsa bubbles. Smells of grasses and light malts. Taste isn’t bad, surprisingly. It’s grassy, but crisp and drinkable, rather than being bland and ordinary. Now, I wouldn’t drink this on a regular basis, but if I HAD to, I wouldn’t mind (too much).

Tasted 28/09/2005.  330ml bottle at Cellar-Vate tasting.
Snappily dressed in green, embossed, bottle and frilly label.  Not much going for it after that.  Thin, pale gold, a little stale and quite watery.  Hints at some nice juicy, honey-like, malt and lemony, zingy, hops but they are almost undetectable.  Would love to gve it another go fresh.  I never even tried it in the Czech Republic.

Bright golden honey hue, with soft foamy white head, with pale malt, toasty malt, floral hops aromas follow through on a medium-bodied palate with a crisp pale malt, fruity note, floral hops, leading towards a smooth maltiness finish.

500 cm3 Can - September 05

Pours pale golden colour with a nice white head. Aroma is flowery and sutile. Taste is somewhat sweet and slightly bitter at the end. Overall a nice Pilsner, but i prefer PU for a more intensive experience.
15 years ago, the pilsener urquel was the only one fore me from czech beer, but now with 4 other czech pilsener budweiser budvar is one of the best.

Pours a yellow color with a decent size that goes away quickly. Sweet malt in the aroma but really not much going on. Flavor is lightly malty with just a hint of hops. Watery finish. Doesn’t really do much for me.
one of the best pilsners i’ve had.  clear golden w/ off white head.  quenching, smooth and clean.  decent.
Balanced a little to the bitter side, aroma of malt with a hint of Saaz. I would drink this as a lawnmower beer if I could afford to.
Golden colour, big bubbly head that goes off rather fast. Pretty nice pilsner smell, the taste is also good - nice bitterness, hops flavour, maybe slightly too much carbonation. Good pils anyway

A Mes rate: 
It has been said many times before but I will say it again. This is really not my thing but as pils go this is certainly one of the better ones. So glad they managed to keep the name after the legal shananigans with those we shall not mention.

The Rate Beer descriptor for the beer style sums up the Budvar very succintly (funny that!). Great hop / malt balance and whilst not a hop head’s delight finishes tight and clean.  I can imagine these beers need to be drunk very fresh.

An excellent czech lager. Blond and clear colour, medium body, thin feel, average carbonation, bitter, abrupt finish. Fairly bitter taste. 
A beer I like driking along spaghetti with carbonara sauce.
The real Bud. This Bud is actually good unlike the beer that stole its name. Smooth, crisp and hoppy lager that is typical of the Czech Republic.
Robe blonde très claire srumontée d’une mousse blanche fugace. Arômes de malt et de céréales. Saveurs de céréales et de houblon amérisant.

On draught at "U Obory", Jabkenice: Golden coloured, medium-sized, long-lasting firm head; sweetish-malty aroma with a distinct tinge of floral hoppiness; mainly sweetish-malty taste; light bitter-sweet finish; quite light-bodied; well drinkable, but not terribly impressive; there are better, but unfortunately unknown Lagers in the Czech Republic !

[bottle from sainsburys] pours light yellow with a light head which does not last. A stale cardboardish aroma ruins an otherwise pleasantly hopped nose, a little grassy. this stale taste comes through again in the palate, body is light and has a dry finish.
very nice pilsner. malty bit hoppy, bit yeasty aroma. fresh crisp malty and fruity taste. finishes fruity and long.

I Like this beer simply because it is the REAL budweis!It is also better the fresher it is like most light lagers/pilsners.Soft body with spicey Czech hops makes American Budwieser look like the pathetic beechwood aged shite that is.
A light aroma and a golden color.  Has a nice white head.  Not overly bitter and has a hint of spice in the flavor.  A nice refreshing beer.

Drank in the Latern Pike Inn, Derbyshire.

Was wanting Budweiser, as it was a hot day and I needed my thirst quenching, and I was given this.
And to my suprise it was lovely, had honey, lemon and orange like notes and very light but alot of flavour for a lager.

Easily drinkable, and Its a pity I can’t seem to get more of it.

Golden yellow (slightly orange) with a very fizzy head that disappears very fast.  Aroma is mostly hop and malt with notes of spices.  Flavours are very well balanced, just the right amount of hop and malt with a fairly bitter, dry finish.  Much better then the "other" Bud....

Smells okay for a pils.  Not particulary good or bad, which for beers of this style means this is pretty good. Especially when you consider my bottle says I should have drank it by March of this year.

A very lively beer.  Fresh aroma, crisp taste, hyperactive bubbles hopping all over the place.   This beer is smooth but the finish is somewhat flat, as if made with stale water.  Not as tasty as Pilsner Urquell-- still the king of pilsners.  Not even close.

I had to re-rate this beer.  The first time I had it was here in the USA as Czechvar.  I wasn’t impressed.  Perhaps it was a little old.  Well, when I was in Germany I had it as Budvar and it was fresh.  Man what a difference.  This and Urquell now rank as my favorite Pils.  Great taste with a good bite, but without a bad or strong aftertaste.  A pilsner fan must try, but try to get it fresth.
50 cl Bottle. Nice golden colour with a fine head. Good aroma of malt and some hops. Very good taste and fine balance between hops and malt, good finish, some bitterness to the end.

I don’t know much about lagers, but this was certainly the best I’ve tried. I was particularly struck by the aroma. Delightful sweet taste with a brief, crisp bitter finish. Easy drinking for a warm summer’s day.

From the bottle: Pours clear golden with bubbly white head that thins fast. I’ve had it dozens of times but this is the first time rating it. 
Smell of bitter grassy (predom. hay and skunky aroma that seems common to eastern european pils.) Not my favorite style. This is a fine example and much bolder in taste than A-B’s interpretation. 
Bold malty flavour.clean finish. 

I prefer a dortmunder overa bohemian pils any day.
Pretty good compared to the American Mass Market beers, but doesn’t compare to Pilsner Urquell. Definitely better than the US Budweiser, though.

This was one of those beers that got me into beers, but after having it again i realise that iv come to better stuff. Aroma is reasonable and slightly sweet. Taste is a bit malty with quite a bit of carbonation, very dry finish. Its worth a bash this fellow as its a bit different to your usual lager, though nothing special.
It’s basically budweiser but it’s a lot better.  A much better Pilsner then it’s American cousin.
On tap at The Lemon Leaf, Prague.  Decent hoppy aroma.  Plenty of bite on top of full sweet malts.  One of the best mainstream pilsners, along with Urquell.

rich golden color , a bit of a stinky smell, 
light carbonation. the beer has a nice sweetness to it without much bitterness.

Light hops aroma with some malt. The color is a rich golden color with lots of carbonation but not much in the way of head. The taste is light and pleasant and not as watery as many pilsners. The flavors of the hops give it a small spice and citrus taste, but mostly you taste the sweet malts. The beer finishes just like it starts. A serviceable beer if you want a pilsner.

Slightly hoppy aroma. Clear golden color w/ a 1 finger head that dies quickly. A tad spicy & malty. IMO, a very solid daily lager. I realize it’s not the greatest lager out there but I’ve always liked it even though it’s a bit overpriced @ $8.99 a 6er. I could drink many of these. A great session beer if I’m in the mood to keep drinking for awhile.

Pours yellowish/golden with a creamy white head.  Short retention.  Cool bottle which is similar to Pilsner Urquell.  Aroma had lemon, butter and saaz hops.  Some apricot and citrus as well.  Very malty taste with a good hoppiness throughout.  Quite fruity.  Terrific malty palate with butter and lemon.  This has to be one of the top lagers in the world.  Very good.

A truly enjoyable beer and an exellent example of the kind. Did i mention that its sweet? :) 
Why anyone buy a corona over this is beyond me.
London - Gold in color, it has a nice sweet hoppy aroma.  The flavor is similar but a little lighter and there is a nice little bite to it.  It was quite nice.

Pours golden yellow with a fine white head that didn’t stay around for very long. Malty aroma with some nice grassy hops, a little metallic. Great palate, finely carbonated, smooth with a crisp finish and a nice mild hop flavour. Really enjoyable-- what a premium lager should be.

If only this was the Budweiser I was used to. Solid pilsener with a nice balance and crisp drinkability. Manages what the US Bud never could....light and crisp while still having flavor and NOT getting gross as it warms a little.
What do ya want in a premium lager? Smooth, crisp, clean aftertaste, easy to drink, not heavy, pleasant hop and carb tingle. This has it alright! Simple, but very nice indeed.

Draught at Ølbaren.
Clear yellow coloured with a white head.
Aroma of malts with notes of fruits and hops.
Flavour of malts and hops with notes of brew mash.
Boring !

500 ml bottle best before 25/04/2006. Pale golden colour with a mostly diminishing fizzy white head. Herbal, bready, and lightly spicy aroma. Toasty and herbal flavours with a lightly spicy and herbal bitter finish. Light to medium bodied, quite dry finish.
Bottled. Average sized short lasting head. Light marmalade colour. Nice yeasty aroma. Low bitterness and quite drinkable.

My next door neighbor became hooked on this while stationed in Germany. His favorite beer in all the world. Found some at his high school reunion this spring. Saved a bottle for me. This is one that has been on my list for a while. 

Crisp, full bodied beer. LIttle citrus undertone and a very nice pilsner. Not my personal favorite category but this is a very fine beer from this group. I have noticed that many of the online sites are selling Czechvar in the US. Its a great beer and should be sold by what it is known in Europe as Budvar. AB doesn’t make a beer by that name. If they did their product wouldn’t be slammed as much as it regularly is at this site.

Very light straw yellow with a semi-smeared clearness to its moderate bubbly body. Thin, fizzy, and elusive stark white head with no staying power. Pops away quicker then soda pop fizz to a whispy broken skim and a light frothy collaring. Lacing is splotchy at best with a bit of separated sheeting deciding to stick after about half the glass.
Crisp, clean nose. Adequate but impartial strength of grains and a dantily tilting spicy/herbal/grassy Saaz induced hopping. More of a corn-like sweetness emerges after a period of warming.
Taste has a mild frothyness about it with a fine tuned grain backing and ascents of sharp, quick little herbal hop pops. Semi-sweetened with a bit of honey bread underneath. Overall, mild, clean, sweet, and perky with that certain zip of Saaz hopping that’s traditionally found in a Czech Pils character.
Nearly perfect mouthfeel and body mixing with the flavors with a supreme creamyness and light corn-edged sweetness along with slight bready tones. Very nice drinker here. I quite liked it. Clean, simple, delicate, and accommodating. Serve at a warmer temp and not ice cold. Much, much, better that way.

Bottle. Had right after a Pils Urquell. Slightly darker than PU with less noticable carbonation. A loose thick white, diminishing head, as opposed to the thin, creamy,  glass clinging head on PU. Less skunk aroma than PU, but not as much malt either. The dominent feature of the flavor is the cleanness. It is not very bitter, but has some bite. There is a little grassiness in the flavor. Moderate body. Another well made, well balanced lager, though PU is more assertive.
Vastly superior to its American counterpart.  Nice golden pour, and refreshing with no aftertaste.  A great lager that any beer lover should enjoy.

It seems to be available only at the Chalet Party Shop chain in Elkhart County and its definitely going out of your way to get a sixer of it.
I had been curious about this beer for quite a while and I was happy when I found it locally. Overall it is vastly superior to that other Budweiser. Just a clean refreshing brew without a bitter after taste.
Bottle. Lovely gold colour. Aroma of Saaz hop and fox (?). Good oily hop taste with long finish.

Bottle. Clear medium gold with a huge white head that vanished quickly but left some pretty lacing. Nose: grassy hops, fresh-baked bread, lemon and pepper. Taste: fresh-baked bread, cheddar cheese, ripe peaches and a touch of grassy hops. The aftertaste is slightly minty and mildly stringent. I’m not a lager fan, but this is probably one of the best I’ve had.

(Draught at Legends sports Bar, Prague.)
Pours pale yellow with a thin white diminishing head. Citric nose. Acidic, hoppy flavour. Medium bitterness. Hints of toffee. Light bodied.

Golden and substantial in the glass with no head to speak of.  Aromas of barley and wheat, some nuttiness.  Flavors of wheat germ and barley, other grains, and some acidity.  Finsih is round with some bitterness, but the mouthfeel is still light and lasting.  A very good lager, but not my preference when it comes to having a beer.

Anyone who has been out drinking with me or read my reviews knows I am no fan of pilseners and lagers.  But I dont mind giving credit where it is due.  This may be the only pilsener I ever liked. Nice clear golden beer with a small white head and some lacing. Pleasant malty hoppy aroma. Flavor is what I wish all the other pilseners and lagers were.  Malty, hoppy, with a mild bitterness.  Good body, crisp with carbonation and easy drinking.  Very Nice..
Thin metallic taste. "Best before" date still 5 months away so it isn’t an age issue nor is refrigeration.   Sour, almost skunky smell.  To me Pils Urquell is the much better offering in this style.

(Bottle 50 cl) Incredibly beautiful full golden colour with a rather huge head. Fresh nose of barley. Lots of sweet malt and less bitternes than for instance Urquell. Velvety soft body. Having tried this on tap at the brewery assures me, that this simply must be the world’s best pilsener. No less.

The bottle poured a clear golden liquid with lively carbonation. There was a medium sized white smooth head that lasted a short while leaving little lacing on the glass. The aroma was the typical skunky pilsner aroma at first but then notes of earth and grass mingling with malt sweetness began to come through. The initial mouthfeel was silky smooth. The flavors of mild malt sweetness are subtle and light. What little hop bitterness there is comes out in the middle and end as it lingers on the back of the palate just as a reminder of the experience.
It’s an avarage brew in a nice big bottle. Aroma is nice, not too good. Nice fresh flavor with a little malty taste. Herbal too. Well, not too great but certainly very enjoyable.
Had this as a draft in Frankfurt Germany.  Poured light brown with a fantastic off white head that left a beautiful lace.  Very malty aroma and nice hoppy bitter taste.  Very smooth and satisfying.

In the states this beer is an average pilsner.  In germany it was about the same.  But in the Czech republic fresh on tap it was amazing.  A nice coppery/gold color with a pure mountainous  rocky head which lasted the whole way through.  (think duvel).  Awesome malty aroma perfectly balanced by sweet earthy and herbal czech hops.  Flavor is perfectly balanced as well.  Sweet pilsner malt with a good hop flavor and bitterness.  Oh so smooth finish.  This rating is for the tap version in Prague, not the bottled version here in the US.

pour out a bottle of budweiser
select,funnel in a bottle of
czechvar@ the original budweiser,
enjoy!!bash american budweiser at
clydesdaleurine@budweiser.com
stainless steel tank flavour in beer.
A very nice pils--although, not a standout like Urquell (it’s tough to best the natives).

The last time I had something that allegedly came from Budvar (Budwiser) I had to throw it down the s-bend.  This poured a coppery gold with a nice densely packed head and small lazy bubbles. Big hoppy aroma mellows quite quickly but doesn’t disappear entirely. Quite a full body for a pils. Bitterness is there but fairly restrained compaired to PU (for example).  This is a flavoursome, above average sessional - I love to try it fresh at the brewery. Give them back their trademark A-B and stop ruining this towns reputation.
Clear pale gold colour with big rocky white head. Sour yeast nose. Mild malt taste with definate yeast notes.

Unfortunately very aged sample. However, as nothing will ever equal the lagertank unpasteurised and unfiltered version I was poured on visiting the brewery lab, no rating will ever do right to this beer for kings. 
Sallow amber beer, no head. Virtually no aroma left, very faraway pale and crystal malt, vaguely nutty and hay. Taste is significantly better: a portlike aroma, walnuts and even some blue cheese wafts. It lacks however the hoppiness of the fresh beer, let alone the infinite complexity of the unfiltered/unpasteurised version - in pilsenerstyle only bettered by the then similar version of Pilsener Urquell. Quite malty still. Light MF, oxydized. Pilsener is not for ageing. No mistake, I will rerate this once I get a really fresh sample - say in Czechia again...

english pint / straw body, inactive, and with a fruitless head. the aroma is a bit lacking, as well as the flavor; herbs, mint (it is minty!), (grain and slight eggwhite primarily in the aroma,) it’s gotta nice zip... smooth, and slightly fizzy. refreshing. you know... overall, i think it’s quite good albeit the "lacking" thereof; and i’m even guessing this isn’t that fresh. so, who knows what i could truly score this.

Pours golden and clea with a short lived white head. The nose comes off as a slightly skunked malt, which I’ve come to expect from every brew that comes in green glass. The taste is very smooth and better than I was expecting. Oddly, I can almost make out a touch of mint in the finish. I haven’t eaten anything with mint, and while reading through other reviews I don’t see any mention, so it might be in my head or some fluke.
much better than it’s american namesake. i didn’t know that this was the original budweiser, but i got it as a czechvar six pack still very good. AB can learn something from this brewery
This beer is clean and crisp little less hoppy then one would expect and the head was on the small size, the lacing was very weak good beer for a hot summer night.

It’s all right--but way too hoppy to make me happy.  I give the brewery much credit for standing their ground in the face of the Anheuser Busch onslaught, but I find it too harsh and bitter to really enjoy.
Good bitterness with a nice bite.  A light body, but it still feels as if you could sink your teeth into it.  I didn’t think this was an amazing beer, but it was pretty good.

Clear golden with a medium white head. Aroma of grain and skunk. Flavor has notes of grass, grain, lemon, herbal qualities and floral hops. Pleasantly sweet, not much bitterness at all. Medium body with subtle carbonation. No lacing, ok head retention. Drinkable.

bottle-i ws very impressed by this fresh spicy pils.  pours a lightl yellow with a small head.  big saaz hop notes-crisp hay and lemon.  This has it all-spicy hop notes, good malt base, grainy flavors and that lemongrass finish.  This is best when fresh.

Excellent beer, not quite as spicey as urquell but very quaffable.  Another fine example of how our country (USA) can take something good from another country and bastardize it.  And then have the gaul to sue the brewery for the rights to the name.
 Re-rate:
Oh how I long for the days of the brown half liter bottle.   Okay, the first culprit I look for, the green bottle stink, the fart in an empty room... Honestly, not so much.  Saaz hops, leaning more towards an ocean breeze rather than spice and no discernable sulfur.    Very round and polished body, no harsh grain or angular edges, very soft with a nice touch of hop spice to crisps things up.   Excellent brew, although a properler handled bottle, ie. no light exposure, is essential.  Don’t be afraid to ask them to open a sealed case for you. 88
Colden in colour. Has a white head.Nice hops in aroma and taste. I think som bitterness and aftertaste is lacking...
I think this is the right one?  Smooth enough, not much foam or lacing. Good enough, a fine start to a Saturday morning.
Clear amber body, aroma is a bit sulfury  Pretty rich and smooth while going down.  Not much of a finish.

Tapped. Yellow/golden colour, decent white foamy head. Bready/hoppy nose with hints of grassiness. Flavour is quite hoppy with huge peak after a few seconds, the finish is quite "vegetably". Bittersweet aftertaste and leaves the mouth a bit sticky.
This was pretty good.  a little bitter, kinda grassy, but quite smooth......
Poursa golden hue with a light fizzy white head.  Aromas of skunk, gras, and just a touch of hops.  Flavors is fairly bitter on the palate, yet smooth going down.

Translucent golden blonde, with almost a greenish hue.  The fizzy cloud of head calmed down quickly, but from start to finish tiny effervescent bubbles seemed to come out of the bottom of my glass, like a champagne.  
This is what a lager is supposed to smell: freshly cut grass Saaz.  
Not very malty, but the herbal hop finish has just enough bite to make you come back for more.  Light mouthfeel, but still refreshing and enjoyable, when you’re in a lager mood, which happens to me from time to time.
Golden color with plenty of carbonation and no head.  Skunky aroma and flavor.  Not as bad as bud, and I bet it would be a lot better fresh.

500ml brown bottle, BB 10/2005...poured chilled into a Pils glass, this beer had trouble with the head, and didn’t sustain it.  I don’t have much to say about this.  Nicely hoppy and a well done lager.  I’m just not that into these beers, although I would drink this again.  It was just fine for drinking right after a long day at work playing with the dog in the backyard.  Just something beery tasting to put down and relax abit before I moved on to a more interesting ale.

Tastes like a flat Pilsner Urquell to me.  Not that it wasn’t enjoyable, but I guess that I measure all of the Czech Pils against Urquell.  That and the fact that my brother in law brought it from Munich to me for nada!

Re-rate 24/02/06- I had forgotten how good this beer was so it was time for a re-rate. Tasted from the fully imported 50cL and the bottled in Oz 33cL (good either way). Bright medium gold bodied with a lot of fine carbonation raising up to a short soapy white head that was mostly lasting. Grassy, tart and tight, lemony sour hops on the nose with a softer note of fresh herbs and sweet honey that just completes it. Fresh, juicy citrus fruits open it up in the mouth. Soft on the tongue with a little spritz from the carbonation. Nice quenching spicy hops and balanced honey and estery malts fill the palate out and follow through into the short, crisp and lightly bitter swallow. A lovely, delicate little ’Budweiser’ that A-B just need to leave alone. This is still a great Czech lager.

Beautiful mid gold colour, head disappoining tho! Fresh ,full and fragrant hoppy nose, hint of malt in the background...superb. Palate is medium bodied, smooth and well balanced. Malty,with a clean fruity hoppy acidity, a fine flavoursome lager. Not to be confused with overpriced imitations.

Bottle, at home.
Light yellow. Light malty and hoppy (flowers) aroma and flavor. Moderate bitter finish.

Better than average pilsener, but not the best I’ve ever had. Just’ allright’, not really something special in this brew. Golden color, clear, white head that goes down fast. Pretty wellbodied, hopbitter. Simplicity is the way to success here, though I like something special in a beer..
A spectacularly simple beer.  It is so right.  Probbaly my favourite standard beer.
Pretty much better than the USA BudWeiser, but it is also too soft, and I will not consider it over a Coke if I am thirsty and I have both options. BUt it was quite cool for heat.
Well i’m not going to analyze this beer like it was someone’s gown at the oscars but I will say that it is one of my favorite easy drinking beers.  Too refreshing on a warm day to hate on.

A good beer. It is sometimes dismissed by beer snobs as just another good light coloured lager. There are other good light coloured lagers? With actual flavour? In my limited experience, I haven’t really found any other lagers, pilsners, anyway, that taste like hops and malted barley in addition to actually being delicious.  If there were more widely available pilsner with strong and pleasant flavour, I might be less generous, but for me, this beer occupies a very essential niche by itself. I am not very experienced with pilsners, but I don’t see how much potential they have to be better. Very good beer in a limited style.
medium head that stays for awhile..basic gold in color...smells a little funky...but not all that bad just nothing exciting

Oh, if this were the working class afte-r a-hard-days-work beer in America rather than the rancid swill that bares it’s true name here! Not a "holy-crap" kind of beer, but nice. Actually kept a head, mild in flavor, nicely balanced.

The american import version of Budvar, the Czech original of Budweiser.  The history is complex, but the flavor is not.  Crisp slightly hopped slightly funked pilsner, medium straw-colored. Clean, crisp finish, slightly pleasant session-beer sour twang to aftertaste.

poured a golden color with little to no head.  Aroma is all skunk.. Which is not all that bad.. Taste is a bit of malty sweetness with a skunky add. Nice medium bitter finish.. If US bud tasted like this I would probably buy it..

Every time I get this stuff, it’s always totally skunked due to the bottle non-coloring.  When, OH WHEN, will those silly eastern europeans take the hint?  Pretty awful from the bottle, but I’d like to try it on tap to see if it tastes better without the intense skunk stink and taste.  And usually by the time it gets here and sits around, the taste starts to resemble urine.
From A Bottle.Light orange in colour small head,light hop aroma,some malt and fizzy sweetness.

Golden Pilsner forms a nice white head that fades to patches of foam .Slight Skunkiness,spicy hops and fresh ground grains.Nice mouthfeel no excess carbonation .Light Malt  sweetness that is dryed up with spicy hop finish.

A clean-tasting, satisfying pilsener. Not a patch on Czech draught pilseners but a fine drink in its own right and a perfect session beer. Classic lager gold colour. Poured with a frothy 1cm white head that - to steal a phrase - was gone in 60 seconds, leaving a disappointingly flat looking brew. Fresh lemony hop aroma but a little one-dimensional. Thin-to-medium body with some creaminess. Some sweet malt and fruit at the front of the tongue and a mild dry finish. Bit of honey in the finish to balance the Saaz hops. A great pre-dinner appetiser. (Bottle)

Thanks to beerhandy for this.  Pours pale gold with a big, frothy white head.  Aroma of malt, some hops and slight thiols.  Tastes better than it smells, with a solid malt and hop backbone and some finishing honey.   Better than I expected.  This kicks the ass of American BMC shit.

Bottle.  Light amber in color.  Nice white head lingers and then fades slowly.  Little lacing left behind.  Rather delicate aromas of grass, malt and spicey hops.  A little musty also.  I would really like to try this one fresh!

It really stinks that this, the true Budweiser cannot use its real name in this country because it is much better than American Budweiser.  Light in color, but not in taste.  One of the better pilseners out there.

Thatnks to IslandHaole for this guy.  Shimmering golden pour, med/small white head, active carbonation.  Aroma is slightly skunky, light hops.  Light sweetness, light bitterness, med/light feel.  Probably the best pils I’ve ever had.
This is a classic Czech Pilsner, delicate Saaz aroma, average head,  a medium bitterness that is slightly less than most.  Has a clean, soft, dry finish.
This is a good Pilsener with a fine soft taste. The only thing is the foam disappeared completely.

[bottle] Bright light gold with little head that quickly formed a small ring.  Nice gentle noble hops aroma with clean malt.  Flavour was of clean, sweet malt with subtle, gentle hops and almost no skunk.  Very clean.  Light to medium body with good carbonation and amost a watery aftertaste/feel.

[on tap in Ceske Budejovice]
Bright straw with a 1/2 cm, lasting white head with okay lacing.  Crisp, very fresh, noble hops aroma and a bit of malt with caramel notes.  Gentle, noble hops flavour, well-balanced with malt, but both subdued, compared to Pilsner or Gambrinus--more of a session beer.  A little bit of Chinese tea flavour, but a clean finish, with no bitterness.  Light body and moderate carbonation.
A nice, good drinkable beer but not a real highlight. Nice sweetish, malty aroma with hop notes. Golden color, averange head. Ligh sweet, hoppy, light dry aftertaste.
Well now. classic pilsner flavor. this is how it is done. I’m getting plentiful fruit aromas and flavors. am i wrong? whatever, i get fruit and crisp, clean grain flavors. very solid.

This beer is sort of a one-trick pony, no big winding complexity but a bit of pure malty sweetness set off with a few classic Czech hops. This beer is exactly what it’s supposed to be and kicks ass with Moravian Schnitzel and potato salad. It even travels better than Plzensky Prazdroj (Urquell) which is a super beer fresh in CZ but whos flavors tend to dis-integrate with handling and storage.
Golden pouring with a nice head which surprisingly not lasted too long. Mild flavour with some malty taste.

Pours gold edging on light copper with a white short lasted head. Mild bready/biscuity malt aroma with a light grassy hop smell there too. Flavour was suprisingly bland compared to what I was expecting. Light sweet start with a mild bitter finish. Feel is a little watery in my opinion too. Disappointing.

Sparkling golden color with a quickly settling pure white head. Aroma is malty and quite representative of the style. Smells clean and fresh with a mild astringency. Flavor is simple and crisp with a malty body and a tickly hop finish. Overall, this is better than most Pilsners but I’m not a huge fan of the style. I give it high marks for a golden lager; definitely one of the best.

Not much head, disappearing quicly. Gold body. Tastes malty-bitter; otherwise very clean on the tongue. No aftertaste I could detct. Much better of course than its namesake from St. Louis. In its style, it is one of the best.
Fresh, crisp and clean. Enticing aroma  that sets you up for a little more flavour than you actually get, dry malt flavour with a smattering of light fresh hops. A very pleasant, refreshing beer.
Clear golden yellow color.  Thin white head.  Acidic and malty aroma.  Clean and crisp tang.  Mild flavor with a hint of malt.  A nice beer in this style.
Now this is a masterpiece! Budweiser is not even in the same league. Very refreshing beer with little to no aftertaste.

There’s no worry about confusing this with A-B’s brew.  This pours a clear golden color with a sudsy white head.  The aroma is of mild malts along with some grassiness.  It doesn’t skunk on you when it begins to warm.  It’s light bodied with mild malt flavors balanced nicely with the hops.  Crisp clean finish with a touch of bitterness.  Refreshing.
Color gold. Compact foam of medium persistence. Good perlage and fizzy in mouth. Light bitter.

a little bit dissapointing for me. i was expecting it to be more like urquell. very drinkable though and much better than the equivilant priced imports. very balanced flavour, no so bitter, and light malt flavour.

A pretty stock pilsener.  has the noble hop aroma that you would expect from a quality czech pilsener.  Less bitter than pilsner urqell.  pours a nice golden color with a finely beaded white head. 
Rather mild malt flavor that is well balanced by a moderate saaz bitterness.  Very "clean" tasting and refreshing, great after summer chores.

(bottle) I split a six pack of this with my future father-in-law. He’s deathly afraid of non-macros and he even liked this.  The aroma was a little weak, and the colour seemed to be fairly light golden. The taste was very good, however. It was pretty light and thin, but had a nice hop-malt balance. The carbonation was great, and it was pretty smooth and clean overall.
(Bottle)  Pours a clear pale yellow body with a small white head.  Aroma of grass, mustiness, and hops.  Slightly bitter finish.

Bottle. Very hoppy, malty aroma with faint tones of Earthiness. Pours a deep golden color that is visible even through the green glass. Head is rich, with a slightly off-white color, but disappears quickly. First sip has a nice, strong bite to it. Taste is richly of hops, with some malt thrown in. Great carbonation that lasts through the whole bottle. Definitely a repeat buy!

Slightly hazy golden color with a nice white head. Malty aroma with hints of green apples and toast. Lightly sweet malts, hints of apple. Moderatley bitter finish.  Drinkable, but I would expect more hop character.

Poured golden yellow with a huge head that left as quickly as it formed. Small but pleasant floral hop aroma. Nicely balanced malt flavor with good body and nice crisp hop finish. Great example of the style.

Bottle:  Aroma is lightly malty (apple) and light hops.  Pours a transparent gold with a white head that lasts 30 seconds.  Flavor is light malt with a lightly bitter and  a somewhat lihgt metallic finish.  Light hop and apple aftertaste.  Would be okay, but the finish really turns me off.
Malt and hop aroma, equilibrated hoppy bitterness, fruity and medium palate fullness. Good lager.
I had this on tap in Germany.  I thought it was a fairly good beer.  Went down smooth.

Bottle. Pale gold with a nice dense off white head. Nose is skunky. Taste is skunky with a good amount of malt in the flavor. There is a good clean taste her that is nice. There is some cardboard on the finish. Really this is a nice beer. The only detracting thing about this beer is the slightly cardboard taste.

Clear golden color with a thin, diminishing white head. Strong aroma of malt with citrus and hops notes. Very good toasty, grainy malt flavor with subtle hops and a slightly bitter finish. Light to medium body, soft carbonation. While not up to the standards of Urquell and Na Zdravi, Czechvar is very good nonetheless, I like its malt flavor a lot.

Crystal clear golden color with a small white head that quickly dissipated. Sweet malt and hop aroma. Slightly sweet malt flavor that has a nice hoppy
bitterness to it. A little thin on the palate
but overall a solid pilsener.
I cannot get enough of this one, nice bitterish taste, not too bubbly. A beer that tastes like the beers tasted let’s say hindred years ago. A true original among the beers. LOVE IT!

Draught.  A gold/urine coloured lager with an oversweet taste.  The aroma is quite hoppy and sticky but again too sweet.  Its reputation is better than its delivery.Score 2.4
Subsequent ratings scored 3.4, 2.7 and 3.4. Average becomes 3.0

I was wondering why this tasted hella flat and nasty, probally cuz it expired June 2003 and its October 2004.  Fuck i hope i dont get sick drinking this shit.  I’ll try looking out next time for a good one cuz i cant accurately speak on it in this condition.
12 oz bottle: Pours a golen yellow with a small white head. A very crisp spicy taste. Second only to pilsner urquell.

(Bottle) It shows a beautiful golden colour, surely darker than other average pilsner. Aroma is hoppy, flowery, with a note of sweet malt. Taste is light malty, light honey flavor. A bit empty, less malty and hoppy than in the past, but still a good "everyday" beer.

My favorite beer of all time.  After living in Prague for a while, it became necessary to make a pilgrimage to Ceske Budejovice, where it’s brewed.  We missed the tour but got to have some of the freshest, best-tasting beer I’ve ever had.  Crisp, refreshing, purely enjoyable.  ’Czechvar’ is available in the US, and it just doesn’t seem the same.  Next time you’re in central Europe, though, seek out the Budejovicky Budvar: guaranteed to make you think twice about all those Belgian beers you’ve been paying extra money for back home.

This is one of the best beers I have ever had.  From the 16oz bottle poured into a pilsner glass.  Incredible mouthfeel, almost buttery if this is the proper adjective.  Smooth so smooth but not bland at all, great european Pilsner flavor, and hop aroma.  Wonderful beer.  Big American lager makers should hang their heads in shame.
Considering I had this at a crappy sports bar in a college town and it was probably about six months old, this was still the best pils I’ve ever had.  Now if I could only find it on stores...
Pours a nice golden color. Aroma is grainy and perfumy. Nice malty/grainy flavor. Not spectacular, but is certainly drinkable.

New Review:
My old review was quite dumb, and I decided to do a rerate. Poured a golden (or dark yellow) colour with a small white head that went away fast. Quite fizzy for a moment. The nose is lemony/hoppy (Saaz I guess), with some hints of honey and malt. Not bad. The taste is nice, though not as wonderful as I once thought it was. The honeyish malt, slightly "dusty" and bready, carries the taste, which is backed by a solid dose of pleasantly bitter Saaz hops. Not as full as I once thought it was, but still a very enjoyable Pils. Also gets props for being one of the beers that got me into the world of craft beers. (+1 aroma -1 palate).

Old Review
Bottled (0.5l). A very fine pilsener. Yellow colour,  a fine but subtle aroma, and a smooth, pleasant taste. I envy some of my friends who tried it in Ceske Budejovice. (5/3/7/4/14)
33 cl. bottle. Simple but subtle nose of hops and malt. Taste also simple, but very smooth with a hint of sweetness.  Bittery finish.  Balance is excellent.
Sampled from brown 500ml bottle. Bright gold, white head collapsed and disappeared fast. No trace of any head halfway through the glass.  Malty/bready aroma. Good malt flavour, dry finish.

(12 oz bottle) Honestly, for all the brew-ha-ha (hehe) over the naming rights, this beer just isn’t worth the trouble; It’s not a bad beer by any means, and it kicks the crap out of American Budweiser, but Czechvar is kind of boring and definitely not on the same level as Pilsner Urquell; However, I did have Budvar in Europe several years back, and my notes are far more positive for that tasting, indicating a very smoky, malty, flavorful pilsener; Unfortunately, this rating is for Czechvar, the version marketed in the USA, and it’s clearly inferior to what I had in Europe; The quality is decent and it is malty and flavorful enough to be pleasant and enjoyable, and the hops lends a balancing bitterness; It’s lightly sweet, certainly less sweet than Urquell, but also much less smoky, hoppy and flavorful than Urquell; But it’s just too thin flavored and the palate is too watery; The nose is fairly light, with sweet, mildly hoppy aromas; Light golden color; The white head shows average size initially, but not so good retention, fading to practically nothing fairly quickly; No lacing
Not my favoutite czech lager at all. Lacks hoppiness, but is very malty. It’s all a matter of personally taste but I prefer any other czech lager
Bottle. Nice yellow colour, with good sized white head. Malty aroma. Crisp, with a well balanced flavour. Good pilsner.

Appearance: clear, pure yellow color, with afine, thick bone-white head, slowly shifting into a tight ring.
Aroma: blank and bare, simple, but not shallow, a hint of hops, dry, but delicate, possessing a stoicly sophisticated character.
Taste: nice little lift of hops enters the tongue, then quickly heads out and leaves the palate in a mellow condition. Light bodied, good balance, miniscule malt, making for an overall very nice, satisfactory lager. Only a few hop notes away from a pilsner like Urquell, perhaps.
After finally sampling this brew, I can understand why Anheuser-Busch has spent so much time, money and energy spanning a century plus to contest this beer’s right to exist. If the Budweiser drinking suckers knew how dumbed down and cheap their version is, compared to the original they swiped from, in name, style, and slogan, who knows, maybe they’d question their choice.
Light yellow.  Aroma is grassy, oaky and bready.  Light, not bad taste a moderately midaverage beer.  Enjoy.

Bottle from Pioneer 74th st NYC,
light yellow color, decent head and taste, knda like BUD but w/o anjuncts
nice beer i could drink many of..

The TRUE budweiser, it’s a damn shame those pricks from St. Louis have name rights in the states.  I was surprised by how mellow this beer was.  It has a beautiful color and very nice head.  The aroma smells what you’d like a lager to smell like, quite good.  The flavor is very crisp, mild and well-balanced.  It’s quite dry on the tounge and has a sort of light aftertaste.  This is remarkably easy to drink and refreshing.  A very well-crafted brew with great distinction.  A great representative of its style.
Yellow colored, no head. Malty aroma. Crispy and carbonated start, nicely hopped ending. Nicely bodied and refreshing pilsner, this beer is the big reason why I started rating beers.

One of my favorite bottled lagers. This beer is like an old trusted friend, you can go and taste other interesting beers, but somehow you know that you can always return to this one for "comfort". The elegant golden colour with it’s nice big head, the fine hoppy and malty aroma and the malty flavor with a fine bitter finish, what more can a lager offer?

Bubbly and not at all like American Budweiser.  This stuff seems to retain the taste of the bottle somehow.  A decent beer, light tasting.  Some people in the UK asked me how Budweiser could legally keep selling beer under its name if the copyright for this Czech beer had been established long before.  I gave them my typical "what are you talking about?" faces to their gibes.

Clear golden yellow with a medium diminishing white head.  Aroma of light bread, herbs and honey.    Medium light watery body with a moderate amount of carbonation.  Flavor of honey, light bread and herbs.  Very uninspiring and boring, but balanced and without flaw.  Highly drinkable. Decent.

Fairly skunky presence at first, of course I should attribute that to the bottle date of 9-03 on it.  A bit of a  cidery twang and a high diactely taste.  It was great to finally find this but with this sample not what I expected

Start off with a head you can float a coin on that lasts forever.  The color is crystal clear golden with eensy weensy bubbles.  The aroma is flowery.  Initially you taste the bite of the hops then the malt with a slighlty sweet light hop finish.  The body is creamy smooth. I could drink these all day and night. I tasted this on tap in a pub in Germany.  The bottled version looses some of the perfection of the live show but it is still quite nice.

Clear straw-colored body, medium off-white head.  Aroma of corn and grassy, lightly metallic hops.  Earthy, dry leafy hops and light biscuity malt with corn flavors and a hint of cardboard.  What’s the big deal?
much better than the wife beater I had on the bar, very refreshing, clean taste, however I cant seem to get a long stay head, will be asking for help from Budvar about this
Had this in Czechia a while back, but am rating the bottled version.   Rather dry with herbal hops.  Very refined and delicate.

Pours a nice yellow with a fizzzy short lasting head.  Aroma is very skunky.  Flavor is a hoppy citrus mix and very bitter at the end.  Probably a little more flavor than a Pilsner Urquell.  Not a bad over all brew once you get past the skunkyness and much better than that other beer that shares the same name.

Slightly skunky, wet paper aroma. Somewhat crisp, light malt flavor. Not as sharp as I was hoping and seemed tired. However, I can tell that this is a quality brew and I bet it’s awesome sampled at the brewery. It just doesn’t import well.

How exciting - a load of Budvar at my local bottleshop with a June 05 BB date! This is only the second time I’ve seen this beer in Australia (in the green 330mL bottles this time.) The first bottle I had was like a bottle of vegetable soup - really weird. The second bottle was better, but still not as good as I recall it being the first time I had it. Light diacetyl in aroma with barely any hop character to be found and some of that nice uncooked spaghetti smell that some Euro pils seem to have. Flavour is lightly malty (far less malty than PU in the bottle) with more spaghetti flavour and a pretty light bitterness. I’ve still got a few more bottles to drink but at the moment it’s just a fairly standard (but nice enough) European lager. I swear it was better than this...
Re-rate: This just isn’t doing it for me. Smells like boiled vegetables and cider, is really sweet with quite a strong hop flavour but no real bitterness. Disappointing. Oh yeah it had a faint funk that kinda reminded me of Robinson’s Chilli Beer too. 2.7 
Re-rate: OK, this beer still sucks out of the bottle in Aus, but it’s good stuff in the Czech Rep. In fact I preferred the bottled stuff to even the unfiltered version they sell at the brewery restaurant (though not to the stuff straight from the lager vessels). The malt character is really beautiful, just pure Pilsner malt goodness. Hops are there but certainly not to the extent of PU etc. Didn’t take notes but I just can’t let my old rating remain.

It was a pleasure to, at last, taste the Budvar. Which is a part of the new danish ’trend’, of buying imported specialities (at a triple price).
Good, but not really that good. Nice yellow color, and nice hoppy after-taste..
Yellow and fizzy...skunky and hoppy aroma...tasted like Budweiser but skunkier and a little bitter...hmmm...go figure...

4/22/04:  Bottle.
Heavily hopped nose and very skunky.  Yellow bodied.  Typical pils characteristics- hops with a slight lemon flavor.  I had this beer several years ago, while living in Germany.  It seemed to taste better then.  (Maybe it does not travel well).

Supeior to the american namesake, but their is no suprises to the beer drinkers of the world, a straight-forward pilsner.

Must try at least, enjoy it in the summer

I have always wanted to try the "real" Bud, having despised the American version ever since my first sip.  What I found is a very drinkable beer.  Sort of a weaker flavored Pilsner Urquell.  As I’m more of a malt man than a fan of lagers I would run out to buy a case, but I also wouldn’t be unhappy to see it on the menu.
bottle. pours an effervescent gold with a thin head that poured big but disappated fast. sharp yeasty aroma.  hoppy a slight sourness to this. smooth finish that leaves a touch of malt.

Very nice Pils.  Puts the budweiser beer of the USA to complete shame.  In my opinion, much better than Pils Urquelles.  I had this on tap in Heidelberg Germany last week.  Nice creamy head.  Golden Pils.  Very refreshing.

Rocky white head, moslty lasting.  Good lace.  Clear yellow body.  Hoppy and yeasty (soap) aroma.  Moderately bitter and a bit watery initial flavour and lightly bitter (averagely bitter finish).  Light body.

This one pours a sparkling gold with a very small, quickly deminishing head.  The nose is sweet and pretty much standard for the type.  Taste is lightly acidic, moderately sweet with hints of bananas, and a bit dry in the end.  The bitterness is upfront and not in the end so much.  It’s very balanced overall.  The palate is actually diverse and subtle once the initial sweetness clears.  A very good beer in its style.

This is my kind of beer,completley BLOWS the socks off the poor American imitation.Good strong pilsner taste,fast dissapearing head,but the taste more than makes up for the appearance.The origional & Best Bud!!!!

Clear golden coloured body with a medium sized white head. Not much head retention and very little lacing.  Doughy characters in the aroma as well as some dried fruit and some yeast. Light body in the taste, some sweetness and then some metallic bitterness, other tastes there were, cheese, cardboard and some hop oil. Average finish with a dry texture.

Beautiful golden beer supporting a creamy white head. Nice nose of clean hops and malt. Smooth slightly sweet with a nice bitter finish. I haven’t had as many samples of this as i have had of Pils Urquell, but this probably should get sampled multiple times as well.
Well it is not very complicated beer but but refreshing.Not deep,not good,not a great beer as it name.Easy drinking water.

Something like what American brewers had in mind when they still had minds.  A good Czech Pilsener with an initially slightly sweet taste evolving to hops dry.  Forms a thick head at the pour that dissipates leaving light and delicate lace on the sides of your glass.
Bottle. Golden color with a big white head.  Malty hoppy aroma, smooth malty taste, medium body, light bitter finish. a good pilsener.

50 cl. bottle. Served in Budvar stein.
Golden; moderate head. Pleasantly hoppy, pleasantly malty, eminently drinkable. Supremely balanced.

Nice hop aroma and pours a very clear golden color, nice white head, the flavor was crsip, clean, balaned and very smooth, nice Saaz bitterness. Move over Urquell there’s a new kid in town!
Stands shoulder to shoulder with Pilsner Urquell. AB should take notes on how to brew a truly outstanding tasting beer! Czechvar IS the true "King of Beers"

Green bottle, BBD 180804: I was expecting this to be skunked, but it was quite fine, slightly aromaic hopping with a little doughiness; clean, balanced sweetness with a metallic tinge and nice, quick bitterness; very smooth; better than expected.
Just one step behind Pilsner Urquell, but it is still one of my favorite beer. Light golden colour, tiny carbonated.
Mid-sip herb, grass and hay, metal. Grainy dry finish.. some Carbonation. Not my cup of pilsner
Well it looks like a pilsner.Pours with a large head which disappeared straight away.Light golden colour,very little carbonation.Watery although with a decent hop taste.But as boring as f...
